name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the provisions relating to summer time (2017/2968 (RSP)).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the request on today’s opportunity to debate on EU summer time arrangements is very timely. The Commission regularly receives questions about the time switch, including from Members of the European Parliament. Some of those doubt that we need to switch time.  As the Commission committed before this House, my services have reassessed all available evidence. This includes the very balanced and complete overview made by the European Parliament’s research services. The evidence is conclusive only on one point – that letting Member States free to apply uncoordinated time changes would be detrimental for the internal market. I am therefore against such a solution, whether that means simply repealing the directive or allowing individual Member States to opt out of the harmonised regime.  Conversely, the findings are inconclusive on human health. Some people seem to suffer from the twice-yearly changes, but this might be well compensated for by the positive health effects induced by increased leisure and outdoor activities. It is unclear whether permanent summer time or winter time would be better for the human biorhythm.  While I am open to consider the summer time issues further, I would like to stress an important point. There are two options that would allow for a continued harmonised approach: stop time changes for all Member States by amending the directive, or leave the summer time rules unchanged. If one were to select the first option, it would also have to be established when to abolish time changes – after the last change to winter time, or after the last change for summer time.  We discussed the summer time issues at the last Council sitting in December at the request of one Member State. I explicitly invited all ministers to let me know if any of them were in favour of changing the status quo. Apart from the one Member State that put the question on the agenda, nobody has done so until now. Today it is your turn.  I very much look forward to the forthcoming debate and welcome the vote on the resolution which will give Parliament the opportunity to voice its opinion in this matter. I am sure it will give rise to valuable elements for reflection. All the more so, since the success of any potential Commission proposals intended to modify the current rules by definition depends on the stance taken by the co-legislators.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: for the PPE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, hundreds of petitions to the European Parliament, a number of national initiatives, at least one oral question every year. This points to the urgency of the problem. Chronobiologist Professor Merrow told us here at a hearing in the European Parliament that 20% of the population has health problems and 80% of the population does not believe that 20% have health problems. Another chronobiology professor, Till Roenneberg, from Munich, tells us that the social jetlag that the time change acts leads to increased smoking, greater consumption of alcohol, caffeine, depression, obesity, Type 2 diabetes, metabolic problems. Direct and indirect costs are estimated to go up to one per cent of GDP. In doing so, the unconvincing concerns why the regime still exists today. Energy savings have not occurred and even more sporting activity is not even proven as a result of daylight saving time. I am glad that you have noted that the Commission is revising this directive, which means that the amendments made by fellow Belet are superfluous. On behalf of that 20%, I ask the Commission to take up legislative activity.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, the truth is that we all generally agree that there is something, called jet lag, which, for those who travel from one side of the Atlantic to the other, from one country to another distant, means that fatigue is accumulating and that it is difficult. And the time change really, both in spring and autumn, would be a kind of “mini jet lag”, but it ultimately affects the health, especially of the most unprotected or the most vulnerable, such as children and, too, the elderly. But as the Committee on Transport and Tourism, we, as the Committee on Transport and Tourism, care very much — especially from the associations of road victims — the accumulation of fatigue that is occurring in the weeks following the change, especially the winter change, but also in spring, since there is a difference that generates nocturnal insomnia and, of course, that accumulation of fatigue. We agree that we must also study — and this was something we agreed on — the benefits, for energy efficiency and, above all, also, because to those of us who are tourism countries seemed to us that our wider schedules were just going to be better. What happens is that, in my country, the schedules are so wide and so complex to reconcile with the hours of stay with the family that we should almost, in Spain, rethink them more drastically and not just because of the time change. But I am pleased that you, Commissioner, are rethinking once again — because I think we need to be assessed — the possibility of changing the schedule. Let it be harmonized, but never have to change it again and improve everyone's health.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. — Mrs President and Honourable Commissioner! There is no doubt that this is the most important issue during the half-year here in Strasbourg, surely why? Because it's very popular and it's interesting for many people and it can be used as a pre-election element in the 2019 spring elections. I am very surprised that the Transport Committee is the one that submitted this resolution, because the study organised in the European Parliament does not necessarily show any impact on transport, and the Commission does not have any study to describe the cost of transport from this time change. I loved it very much too, even surprised, that Mr. Svoboda mentioned that the one-hour amendment leaves such a huge impact on health. Then we, who travel from Latvia, for example, one hour every week to the European Parliament, are in a continuous jetlag. Which, of course, is not the case, so I would call for common sense to be maintained and done either a proper study and then talk about the issue, as several MPs propose in this resolution, or end the matter.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ALDE Group. Commissioner, you are responsible for this time change, winter and summer time. You said you don't want a patchwork in Europe. But we do not want that either; we want to abolish the time change, and do so uniformly throughout Europe. It was introduced once to save energy. In fact, energy saving is in the range of 0.1 to 0.5%, as many studies have shown. What you might save on light in the evening with prolonged daylight, you need in the morning for heating or even in the morning for light. From this point of view, there are many negative effects that have already been addressed. And that's exactly what it's all about, that's what drives people around. It's even negative for the climate, you noticed, because the sun is practically generating CO2 pollution for a long time, which is practically in the evening, and that's not good for the climate... (intercuses)... no, that's so, actually, let me finish! Otherwise, as far as health is concerned: many people suffer from it. According to a long-term study by the employee health insurance in Germany, there are 25% more heart attacks right after it, 15% more sick leave, 12% more depression, and there are deficiencies in concentrations that lead to lower school performance and more traffic accidents, which are usually caused by less sleep. in the morning, especially children and young people are involved. We are always fighting to have fewer road accidents, and the opposite is indeed the case. I don't suppose that can be! Furthermore, one must also consider: in the case of animals: the cows give up to 10% less milk. This has to do with the fact that we all have an internal clock, all living beings; this has to do with the position of the sun, for example, and with the day/night rhythm of the Earth, and we interrupt that. Chronobiologists were awarded the Nobel Prize for having noticed them what is important for the organism. And we want to override it? There are 140 countries around the world that have already made the transition 50% — Russia, for example — because they have noticed that there is a decline in gross national product, which of course they did not want. Why do we want to be dumber than Mr Putin, for example? So: health, traffic accident... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, the change of time has been criticized for some time. It is clear — and several studies have shown this — that energy savings today are marginal and that, however, there is an impact on citizens' biorhythms that can have health consequences. At the same time, it is also true that we all agree that enjoying more hours of sunshine after the working day improves our quality of life or that, for example, there are countries where tourism improves the more hours of light in the summer periods, for example in the Mediterranean area. We therefore find it reasonable for an in-depth impact study to be carried out on the effects of the change in time on the various dimensions of health, work and energy consumption, and throughout the European territory, bearing in mind that this is something we have known for a long time to be unnecessary and harmful.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as far as the transport sector is concerned, the change of time which takes place twice a year has a double impact. The first is that the lack of sleep it causes for many fellow citizens poses a real problem of road safety. This is the cause of a large number of accidents involving particularly the most vulnerable road users, and I am thinking of pedestrians and cyclists. There is a second important thing that we forget: the freight transport sector in Europe, which is not well fixed, has to face additional administrative burdens related to the change of time every time we switch to summer or winter time. If we add to that the fact that today, yes, it represents a public health problem for humans, there are negative effects on animal welfare. I think we have enough arguments to vote in favour of this resolution by Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism in order to call on the Commission to take over this subject and to remove the change of time that is no longer necessary.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as you can see on this watch is 9.15. The undersigned, but I also think all European citizens, starting with Italian citizens, would expect an important House like the European Parliament to be here speaking, for example, the five millions of poor Italians, talking about the four million unemployed Italians, talking about the dramatic problem of this continuous criminal invasion of hiding. We would expect to talk about the real problems of the country, and instead in a crazy way, in a crazy way, in a ridiculous way we are here talking about whether to abolish or not abolish daylight saving time. Then I propose to the European Parliament, I propose to my colleagues, propose to move the clock hands one hour back. That would lead to the savings for European citizens and Italian citizens of EUR 250 000, which we should pay back for a pointless discussion we are having at the moment. I really hope to bring this Parliament to talk about the important issues, the issues of work, the issues of the continued invasion of underground, the issues that the citizens expect today. America talks about taxes, talks about jobs, talks about defending borders. We are here in a crazy way talking about a pointless subject for the interests of European citizens and for the interests of Italian citizens.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, since 1981, when the countries of the European Union have alternately applied winter and summer time, there has been a lot of discussion about whether and whether this practice has real advantages or not. The actual time - or rather the solar time - is the winter time. Summer time is a method, an agreement that has been reached between the States, so that work can begin one hour earlier and that we can exploit more sunlight. However, the opinions of workers differ according to the type of work they perform; others prefer the alternation of time and others do not. However, advocates of the abolition of daylight saving time argue that the alternation of time results in disruption of the quality of workers' sleep and work, and in the long run health problems. For all this, the European Union must ensure that, if it abolishes summer time, it will cooperate with the States so that the daily lives of their citizens are not affected.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there is clearly a great many studies. And there are just as many opinions about daylight saving time and winter time. In particular, I remember that the daylight saving time reduces accidents on the road. That seems to me a strong argument. There would, of course, also be shady sides. What we propose in the alternative resolution — a very moderate text — is that the European Commission calmly weigh the pros and cons on the basis of scientific input. That doesn't have to happen from today to tomorrow. A lot of research has already been done, but in a number of Member States and a number of regions. Of course, such a decision can only be taken if such an investigation is carried out throughout the European Union. We are convinced that such a thorough investigation will provide us with the necessary information, which we can then continue to work with. We expect the European Commission to come forward with a concrete proposal. Moreover, the issue is not urgent either. There will be enough work here in the coming months on which we can and should concentrate our priority.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: — Mr President, the summer period is a historic relic of the 1970s, when it was aimed at making savings on expensive energy costs. What we see now is that those energy cost savings are very marginal. However, the transition to summer time has many negative effects. We must not come down here to talk about ourselves, healthy meps who do a lot of work, but we must look at the internal clock of man, from which we have seen that man, without difficulty, does not adapt to the twice-yearly movement of clocks. Difficulties exist especially in young children, older people and sick people. Among them, we also bear responsibility. Sunlight changes for a few minutes a day. We all feel how it's different at different seasons in the South and North, but this performance is a human-politically decided, pretentious one-hour transfer twice a year. We people can also politically decide to stop it, because we have made that decision on graft. This initiative proposes that the Commission should bring a more detailed draft of the summertime arrangements to Parliament and the Council. Even after this — as it is today — each member country can decide which time zone it belongs to and also decide whether to stay in summer or winter time. However, both of these resolutions clearly state that the European Union line must be a unified solution so that all countries either stop graft or — if the majority wishes — do not yet do so. Colleagues, I ask that you support people with sleep problems and allow you to give up summer time.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: – Madam President, I think during my entire lifetime this has come up, and probably in most Member States you’ll have heard this over the years: should we change the clocks or not? Just a point for my colleagues: as somebody who was formally in the airline industry, believe me, jet lag isn’t a clock moving forward or back one hour, twice a year. Jet lag is something completely different. I think the original directive was quite logical in terms of harmonising the biannual change, so clearly at least we changed the time at exactly the same time throughout Europe and throughout the European Union. I’m personally totally unconvinced by the scientific reports which, quite frankly, are inconclusive. Furthermore, on the grounds of subsidiarity, this must be a Member State decision and should not be a decision made by the European Union and imposed on Member States. A proposed assessment by the Commission in my view is a complete waste of taxpayers’ money at a time when there are far more important issues which we should be focusing upon in Europe. I therefore say, certainly on behalf of my delegation, that we shall not be supporting these proposals – despite all of the hard work done by colleagues.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: — Mr President, the Commission promised at the beginning of the period that it would be big on big issues and small on small matters. It would be high time to show that it could even be that average size on this issue. The more northerly you go, the greater the differences arise over the course of the day. I can tell you that the sun set on Utsjoki on 26 November and then rose on 16 January. If anyone on the commission believes that by moving the clock an hour there or here it will have an impact on Utsjoki, then welcome to reality, you have no knowledge of it. If the sun does not set at Berlaymont, then it will rise, however, on the Utsriver on May 17, after which it will fall on July 26. If you guys think you can make a difference, then welcome again!

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: — Madam President, the Commissioner said that the studies are not conclusive, but it is true that there are studies that point to negative impacts on health, agriculture, road safety and also on reducing the quantity and quality of sleep. I, Commissioner, would recommend the precautionary principle in favour of health. She also says that summer time favours leisure activities. I would say to the Commissioner that in order to encourage leisure, we need to reduce working hours and share work. On the other hand, as far as energy saving is concerned, one of the very important arguments put forward to justify these changes also seems to be insignificant. Galician and Galician suffer much more from these impacts since our geographical position is that of Portugal or the United Kingdom, but we are one hour ahead, with the time of Germany. That is why we are asking that this directive be amended and that daylight saving time should not be changed.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: — Mr President, believe it or not, but banana flies are quite substantially related to this debate. Namely, Hall, Rosbash and Young, winners of last year's Nobel Prize in Medicine, studied the circadian rhythm and internal clock of banana flies and found out that the biological clock is also amazingly accurate and sensitive in humans. Disrupting it can have far-reaching consequences. Now the internal clock is disturbed twice a year by moving the clocks. This causes health disadvantages and sleep problems for many. We need to get rid of the transfer of clocks in the EU. Further studies are no longer needed to support this decision, as they can be found over many years. I sent 60 source references to you this morning, colleagues, and the outcome of studies drawn up around the world is uncommonly clear. There is no good in moving the clocks, but there is plenty of inconvenience. I hope this decision relies on research knowledge rather than first-hand emotions.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Madam President! I'm glad that this discussion occurred, because 65 years ago, when the Communists were introducing this time, I was explaining to my father that it was idiocy. Finally, there was a discussion on this issue in the European Parliament. Of course, the Member States can deal with this. It is enough that when daylight saving time is carried out, to order that children go to school not at eight o'clock, but at nine o'clock, we start work not at eight o'clock, and at nine o'clock. And time will be changed and nothing will change. But I ask myself: it's not about the biological clock, it's just that twice a year we disrupt people's time, introduce monstrous confusion in transport, everywhere, you don't know what cholera for. Because that, I repeat, doesn't change anything. And in general, in my opinion, this change of time is the same thing that the French revolutionaries introduced — that is, the special revolutionary calendar. The Soviets would turn the rivers around so they would flow the other way. It is a manifestation of man's hubris, an attempt to violate natural relations and replace them with artificial ones, introduced by man and I am against it. And besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. A day has 24 hours, which means we won't gain an hour with daylight saving time. Arguments that the time change gives us the opportunity to do leisure activities outside longer in the evening, or that more people go shopping after work and therefore consumption is being pushed up, I just can't understand. These arguments are disproportionate to the health impairment of many citizens caused by the time change. Secondly, in the eyes of some colleagues, there may be more important problems in this world than the arbitrary turning of the watches. But those who really guide the time change psychologically and in terms of health will see it differently. And these are the citizens who are struggling with insomnia and diseases, the farmers in livestock production, the entrepreneurs who are facing high conversion costs, or the people involved in a traffic accident because of fatigue. All of these and much more will thank us if we manage to get rid of the nonsense of time change. Thirdly, about 400 million Europeans do not care whether the time change is there or not — they do not suffer from it. But 100 million suffer from this, and which, however, to a very large extent and extremely. I am fighting for the abolition of the time changeover because it does not make the 80% of the EU population worse, but the 20% is much better. Ladies and gentlemen, please vote in favour of the abolition of this unsaid time change.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let us look at things from the right perspective. The argument in 2000 that changing the hour helps us save energy is no longer valid, especially given that other energy efficiency measures are already widely implemented in all the Member States of the European Union. Currently, the number of negative consequences exceeds that of benefits to justify this practice. Starting with various health problems, such as an increased risk of heart attacks for women and the elderly, up to a 30% higher rate of road accidents in the period immediately following the change of time. Also here, let us not forget that the change of time generates additional costs and administrative burdens for certain economic sectors, especially for transport and tourism. My opinion is that we should eliminate this game with the change of time. Why? Because, for example, this would help improve the long-term planning of freight and passenger flights. That is why I ask the Commission to reassess and revise this directive.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: - Madam President! There are few topics such as the duty to change time, which are of similar resentment in all almost Member States. Both technologies and our lifestyles are changing so rapidly that this practice, justified in the early 20th century, instead of benefits causes many inconveniences and even serious health problems today. Given that the duty to change time has its origin in Community law, the action of European institutions is also needed to abandon it. Of course, before we make the final decision to forgo rearranging watches, and as to which time: winter or summer is better, we need a robust analysis of all the arguments and costs. The European Commission should look closely at this and, if socially and economically justified, review and amendments to the Directive on Daylight Saving Time Understanding.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, it was about time to stop unhealthy practices in Europe, practices which cause harm to children, grown-ups and domestic animals. The practice, which was invented to serve the interests of a war economy, a practice introduced by Tsar Nicholas II and Kaiser Wilhelm II, practices loved by no less than Hitler and Stalin. So what are we waiting for? What is the problem? Let common sense prevail and let’s accept that the laws of nature are more powerful than the laws made by man, even by women and men in this powerful Parliament. And to those who believe that by changing the time on our clocks and on our wrists – that’s a shamanist way of thinking – that it can influence the sun to create more light, they are wrong. I’m sorry to say that. But by way of consolation, you will survive without Summer Time.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, an opinion poll in the Netherlands today shows that 62% want to move away from the clock. Millions of people suffer from the clockwork twice a year. Parents and children get a headache or feel very uncomfortable. I know people like that. Family life becomes disrupted. Families and businesses are bothered by moving the clock forward or backward for an hour. Think also of road accidents and heart attacks shortly after the change of time. Why is the European Union harassing its own citizens? It is a useless ritual and does not save energy, which was once the goal. The European Commission must propose that we continue to maintain daylight saving time or winter time in future. We already have enough research, even of the winners of last year's Nobel Prize in Medicine and the study department of our own Parliament. Angry citizens have already handed me tens of thousands of signatures. In other countries there are action committees and in the Council there is support from Poland, Finland, Estonia and many more countries. What are we waiting for? The European Union is not only for large companies and large countries, is it? We are also there for mothers, children and elderly people who get out of their rhythm due to this strange ritual. I've talked to people from Microsoft. They say it's very simple to adapt computer systems all year round. Mr President, we have been talking about this for three or four years. This seems to me to be a crown jewel by Frans Timmermans: 'better regulation'. The European Commission can very easily simplify the lives of 500 million citizens in Europe, and we must seize that opportunity. We really do not need time consuming and expensive research for that.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: Madam President, Commissioner. The natural rhythm of us humans is determined by the rising and setting of the sun. Today's EU summertime rules are getting the biological clock out of step. No scientific study has yet been able to prove positive effects on human health. I therefore call on the Commission to provide scientifically comprehensible evidence here that justifies maintaining summertime. More important than the rhythm of the economy is the natural rhythm of people's lives. Perhaps in the 1970s and 1980s the introduction of the time change was justified because Europe was divided into different time zones and this was then a contribution to the better functioning of the economy and to the unification of Europe. Today, Europe should put more emphasis on people's health and begin to listen to people's internal clock. Having overcome small-state affairs today, we need a solution acceptable to Europe and to the people with its internal clock. This is a requirement that is by no means part of the carnival in Germany, but must be taken seriously.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: — Madam President, I have a feeling that they could argue probably for days without agreeing to whether a scientific study is for or against the abolition of the clock shift. However, I think we can ask one thing: when this Directive was adopted, which we are discussing today and whose change we want to implement, what were the consultations with citizens? How many citizens wondered about whether or not the weather should be changed, or was the directive itself enacted? We can ask based on what decisions other countries in the world have made to abolish the clock shift? Was it a stupid decision or a wise decision and are we stupid or wise if we are going to maintain the existing condition? I would say in the end: do we have to wait for the civic initiative to gather a million signatures so that in this House and in the Commission this issue begins to be considered as an important issue, not as irrelevant, as some MPs point out.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, if the Commission were to bring here a proposal for a directive proposing that we move the clocks twice a year, I believe that this directive would be absolutely knocked out. It would be considered absolutely unintelligent. Once and for all, the time has already passed for such a shift of clocks. We know that at one time the idea of directive and movement of clocks has been that this could save energy. However, energy efficiency and technology have been soaring since those times, and today it is known that the movement of clocks does not achieve any mentionable energy savings benefit, but instead numerous studies show how much harm it causes to human health, for farm animal welfare, agriculture, road safety, etc.. Several of these areas have been assigned. When we consider how useful and important that directive is today, we must look at the benefits and disadvantages that it brings. It is suggested here that the matter should be further investigated and clarified. We know that this has been clarified and researched for many years internationally in different Member States, and now we should take the decision to repeal that directive.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! You gave us the following choice: firstly, it must be uniformly across the European Union. Consent. Second, it could be: either we maintain the status quo or we change. And as we change, then I wish we would limit ourselves right away: we're just talking about winter time. Imagine daylight saving time, eight o'clock in the morning in Brussels. This is gloom, this is almost midnight. It's different in Warsaw, or Tallinn. In Brussels, by contrast, it is a very different time. Another thing: it rained arguments that don't necessarily contribute that much. Colleagues, don't be angry, but if you refer to what Stalin did and how the flies behave, how it affects the cows, I would leave it completely on the side. However, as regards transport, winter time has the advantage that the propensity for accidents is much less if we start the journey later. And there was an element here a bit confusing. I don't quite understand him. A colleague was showing the clock Saying it was nine o'clock fifteen showed the eighth fifteen. No. It would have been tenth fifteen. Also this needs to be understood. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

text: blue-card question. – Vice-President Liberadzki, I talked about banana flies – fruit flies I think the word is in English – and I did so because the Nobel Prize for Medicine winners concluded that the internal bio-clock of banana flies is not that different from that of humans. Would you be prepared to study that result and maybe take some conclusions from that? So would you then agree that maybe fruit flies are relevant for this discussion?

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — Madam Vice-President Hautalo! That's how I want to get acquainted and obviously knowledge never too much. My intention was to bring our discussion back on such very serious tracks that this is about unity across the European Union. It's about emphasizing that certain historical arguments are far behind us, and considering that winter time — which I wanted to lead to — as we understand it now, this is the right one. And finally in seven weeks, we're back to daylight saving time, so that our debate here is not going to contribute that much at the moment.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Madam President! If I hear the horror scenarios that are being presented here, then I can only be amazed. In the US, there is a long-term study that switching to summer time reduces the incidence of accidents — does not increase — and humans need sunlight. The sun shines just as long. Mr Liberadzki said that the sun only rises in Brussels at eight o'clock. It will be dark at ten o'clock in December when we make the transition to daylight saving time. This means that the arguments must be examined and weighed. That is why I am in favour of Mr Belet's request. Why don't we discuss the full moon here? So I always hear that in my country, 25% of people suffer from the full moon 12 times a year; they can't sleep. When I see where depression occurs: where sunlight is missing, depression arises. We should take the opportunity to give people more sunlight with the current regulation with one hour of summer time. That's why no changeover.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, at home and in the European Parliament, we are having an heated debate on alternation of time, but citizens should know that in our plenary session we do not pay more than an hour of time. Because we devote a lot more time to economic, social and security problems. But the alternation of time burns a large number of citizens, and it is therefore also our duty to address their challenge. Therefore, I believe that there is a need to see that energy savings have not been proven, but that, on the contrary, alternation of time has an impact on the health of citizens. Of course, there are people who want to spend more time outdoors in the summer, I'm among them, because I also like to play tennis until nine o'clock in the evening in the summer, but that time me in the morning no one adds. So I am in favour of treating health as the biggest argument and to support a resolution calling for the abolition of time and calling on the Commission to act.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, scientific studies on the provisions of the European Union relating to daylight saving time have not come to definitive conclusions but would have signalled the existence of effects negative effects on human and animal health and the safety of road traffic. Various citizens' initiatives highlighted existing concerns in relation to the current half-year hour change. Troubling twice a year the biorhythm of European citizens would therefore seem to bring harm. However, even on economic advantages, the debate remains open. The searches carried out are not, in my opinion, exhaustive and I am not convinced by the approach of some of them. I would not, moreover, want us to contradict the EU's climate and energy policies. In the light of the mixed results, I believe that a legislative body such as the European Parliament should be able to express itself only on the basis of certain knowledge. The Commission must conduct a thorough assessment of the directive in all Member States and not just some of them, and only after, if necessary, make a proposal for a review based on the results proceeds.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, studies show that the change of time has an impact on health, transport and even European industry, while at the same time not reducing the cost of energy. It negatively affects the work. At the same time, however, it gives more time for recreation, and the effect of sunshine is positive. It should be understood that the effects are different depending on the geographical location of each country. So the countries closest to Ecuador do not use the time change because the East-West difference throughout the year is small. I think we need to establish a flexible system, such as the one in force in Brazil, where the time only changes in the southern part of the country. Therefore, in order to avoid these processes and conflicts, the principle of subsidiarity must be given the opportunity for various States to choose the best solution, depending on the geographical position of the country. I consider this to be the most correct positioning.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, no one here today denies that there are inconveniences and disadvantages associated with the transition between summer and winter time. But, as the Commissioner said, perhaps they will be compensated for by the advantages. Because just imagine we abolish daylight saving time. We'll have an hour less daylight for seven months. Done with the nice summer evenings with friends on a terrace or in your garden, go cycling with the kids or go jogging. As a result: less quality of life. Suppose we would say: we abolish the winter time. Well, that's not an option. Because that means that five months in the morning it will be finished an hour later and that the children will have to cycle to school in the dark. Very unsafe. If I put everything together, I would say, let's use common sense. For me, the current system may be preserved.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: — When I listen to this debate, it is obviously a question that causes very different views, including such that it is an irrelevant topic which, because of all the other very important challenges facing the European Union, does not actually belong to the European Parliament, but is it really so? Recently, more and more calls, including Europeans, as well as the finding that the rationale for changing the clock no longer holds up, that changes in the clock have a negative impact on human health, risk of road accidents and others, to increase administrative costs, and these are all measurable and financially evaluated consequences. It is right, of course, to face different arguments and to put on the table the findings of profession and science. However, we must also follow the principle that the rules of nature prevailed first. Why nature needs to be corrected again and again and put some artificial legalities and rules to it, because sooner or later this retaliates.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, the clock change disrupts the harmony between human biological clock and the external clock, and recovery, depending on the individual, requires a period of 4 to 14 days. Harms to health are clear and proven. The energy improvement and benefits are reduced in proportion. There have been initiatives in several countries to abolish the conversion. In the Hungarian Parliament, our initiative is not supported by the majority because it expects harmonisation in the European Union. This is our chance to get this started. And one more remark: here many people who talked about the benefits of daylight saving time will look at uniform time as winter stays. No, it's not. The Commissioner has also indicated that he prefers to maintain daylight saving time.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, it was worth getting up early for this debate because I have learned about banana flies and all sorts of very interesting things that I really did not know about. This is an issue that people are interested in. I have got volumes of comments, so let me read you a few.  Tommy Donnelly: ‘We tried this before, about 40 years ago, to change. Before we start, maybe someone should discover why this change was discarded. If it was not practical then, it may not be practical now’.  On the other hand, Patrick Brennan: ‘Yes, please change this ridiculous change. It would be most welcome in industry such as pharma, especially where standalone instrumentation might be used and which might not be synchronised to a network clock. One less nuisance and data integrity headache. Then Ríona Meehan: ‘We are divided in this house. My husband, a farmer, wants the time to continue to change for winter and summer. On the other hand, I do not want my children coming home in the dark and going to school in the dark’.  So, I was going to suggest maybe a referendum but we might get a very close result, and that might be dangerous. Thank you.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, we have expressed our opinion here. I believe that we need to express the opinion of the citizens. I come from the industry, and you know that it was very difficult when they were working 3 shifts and changing hours, we were always late at work. Kids, we need to change every clock in the house. I do not believe, I do not think that if we are a Union we should not have the same time. I live in Romania, when I go to another country I take care to change my watch, not to be late. These are absolutely normal things, and then my biorhythm colleagues spoke. You can not dictate the body to adapt, today I give the clock forward, but the body also adapts. I support the report and hope that we reach a uniform hour in the European Union.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Madam President! I also think it is an important debate. I've also learned about both banana flies and health, and if it's really true that a twice-a-year shift creates major health problems, then I think we should start a big campaign to stop all travel from east to west and vice versa. Then it's much, much more dangerous than people have discovered! Then people should lie and be sick around us! This house should be full of sick people, since many change time twice a week! No, I love daylight saving time. I think those long bright evenings when those who want to work can work longer where you can enjoy themselves where you can be out. It's not just in Denmark — in Denmark it's absolutely wonderful — also in the Netherlands I've experienced it. Well, also in Norway, although the sun barely sets further north. I have experienced it myself in Strasbourg. The bright summer evenings, the hot summer evenings are wonderful, and I think you guys who just think it can be free to abolish, to take these wonderful evenings from people, you don't realize what you're doing. Don't, however, let's keep our lovely... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, summertime was first introduced more than 100 years ago. At the time it brought two great benefits: the enjoyment of the solar day, synchronizing the working hours with leisure times, and the savings in the energy bill, which today is only marginal, as we all know. At first glance, it seems that this resolution is only concerned about the inconvenience of having to change the timetable, but this nuisance has to be accurately measured, since all the evidence collected so far seems to be inconclusive. In health it is important to consider, on the one hand, adapting to an hour of difference in circadian rhythm and, on the other hand, the gains we have from greater sun exposure in diseases such as depression, osteoporosis, cardiovascular diseases and respiratory diseases. However, whatever decision we make, we must act with caution and responsibility when we ask to discontinue the biannual clock. We need to remember, on the other hand, that if this decision can fall within the competence of each Member State, and that is what could happen and what we risk, we will create an even more difficult timetable to manage. On the other hand, there are no three time zones, there are four time zones in the European Union. Let's not forget the Azores.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! I, too, believe that this debate and the exchange of views is extremely important because the issue is extremely important for the citizens of the European Union. I don't want to cite all the arguments for time to stop, because during this debate all the arguments for abolishing the change of time have already fallen. We were talking about health, economic issues. Almost every speaker has cited plenty of arguments. We agree almost everyone on this issue, over political divisions, which is not very frequent in this House. Finally, which is very important, the citizens of the European Union want to see the change of time. All kinds of initiatives that are being created in many European Union countries on this issue have also been cited here. Accordingly, the question is: what are we waiting for? Let's keep that time.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Madam President! Since opinion polls show that there is growing support in many societies for stopping this twice-change of time in a year, then we should resolve this. Because it's not a question of what time in a country is supposed to be: whether summer or winter — that's a decision a member country is supposed to make. Whereas the point is for us to stop changing time twice. There are numerous initiatives on this issue, also at the level of parliaments: in Finland, Poland. In Poland, this debate was finally stopped on the grounds that it required a change to the directive. So since this type of work is even going on at parliamentary level, it demonstrates that there is a lot of public support for the cause. A lot of arguments arrive, the economic ones, the health ones. But it seems to me that since these types of opinions in the societies of the Member States of the European Union are increasingly common, we should not underestimate this problem.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome the debate and your different suggestions. Let me get back to you on a few of the points. First of all, let me stress again that the time shift has to be coordinated through EU rules. Uncoordinated national time change in the course of the year would create very significant problems for the good functioning of our internal market, notably in the transport sector. If we ever decided to stop changing the clock, it has to be done throughout the EU in a synchronised and unified manner. Regarding health problems, it is true that the body has to adapt to the time change in March and October. Some people are more vulnerable and have more issues with the change than others. That is true. On the other hand, as some of you pointed out, other studies show that longer exposure to daylight and more opportunities for leisure and sport have a positive effect on people’s health. Whether these gains compensate for the disturbance remains unclear, but I can see that this is an important topic for you and the citizens that you represent. I am very much looking forward to the vote and the resolution later today.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure, we have received two motions for resolutions. The debate is closed. The vote will take place today. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I support the motion for a resolution by the European Parliament which calls on the European Commission to end the twice—yearly switch between summer and winter time. And there is a good reason for that. Last October, the European Parliament’s Research Service published a study on EU summer—time arrangements.It emphasised that the benefits of daylight saving time are ‘marginal’ – because what you save on light you spend on heating. It also found that negative consequences for health are ‘more severe’ than previously thought. Also, animals suffer from the biannual time change, which has a negative impact in the Member States where agriculture delivers strong economic value. The European Commission has to come up with a proposal regarding this issue. However, depending on the proposal, I believe that we still have to support a harmonised approach on this matter across the Union.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - Economic and economic efforts in the Union should be directed towards the common objective of improving the quality of life of each inhabitant. An important component of this quality is primarily health, which is also negatively affected by changes during the year in the form of summer and winter time. Analyses show that the economic benefits, including energy savings from the alternation of time, are negligible. Of course, the benefits from a longer day in summer and the possibility of leisure activities during spring and summer are positive. Regardless of these benefits, health promotion should be a priority. The human body has its natural biorhythms, which such changes negatively affect. Disruption of biorhythms disrupts a person's health and at the same time increases the financial costs of its protection and correction. For important findings in chronobiological research, three researchers won the Nobel Prize in 2017. The latest research has shown that the effect on human biorhythm may be more severe than predicted. More than 20% of people have health problems with the alternation of time. Even those who do not experience these problems should take this into account.

name: Ivari PADAR
text: in writing. — The initial backwarding of the clock was energy saving. Years later, however, there is no evidence of great energy saving, but according to surveys and surveys, there are examples of how this affects people's lives in other areas. Swirling the clock has negative effects on human health, causing fatigue, migraines and sleep problems. It is particularly difficult to adapt to clockwork in the elderly, as well as in children who experience sleep problems, which may affect their academic capacity. Adapting to the clock can take the human body from four days to two weeks. This practice also affects the animal health and the agricultural sector, where temporal change leads to losses in the income of the dairy sector. Also in the transport sector, numbers have shown that the number of accidents is higher in the week following clockwise, and can be caused by sleep problems and difficulty concentrating. Citizens have expressed concern about this practice, and 62% of people want to end it. There have been enough research on this topic, and of course we should proceed from scientific analysis. However, practice has shown that clockwise has a negative impact on a large part of our citizens, so we have sufficient reason and motivation to end it. Human and animal health are very important, and first and foremost, one should stand up for this.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – This motion is asking for the consideration of stopping the annual summer—time change of clocks, or at least to allow each Member State to decide individually on this matter. One has to note that the concept of Daylight Saving Time (DST) was introduced to save energy. This practice may have made sense in the past when lighting made up the major part of energy consumption in the household. However, today’s energy expenses are different. For example, the cost of air conditioning outweighs the benefits of not needing lighting. Energy saving lighting further reduces such expenses. Many also argue that DST has negative health effects, leads to productivity loss, and increased risk of accidents. This mainly results from sleep deprivation that takes place until the body gets used to the new timing. Studies have shown that this period correlates with increased cardiac arrest rates by 24%, work—related accidents by 6%, traffic accidents by 8% and a productivity loss of nearly 20%. Finally, and most essentially, we have to look at the impact DST has on our schoolchildren. I am not happy with seeing kids heading to school in darkness. Any change in the current system must give priority to this issue.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: in writing. — I am in favour of abolishing the time change. However, I also think that before we finally abolish summertime, we should thoroughly examine the reasons for and against in a study. That is why I am in favour of the agreed resolution.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions concerning Russia, the case of Oyub Titiev and the Human Rights Centre “Memorial” (2018/2560 (RSP)).

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: author. — Mr President, here we are dealing with the recent arrest of the head of the Chechen Memorial organisation based on trumped-up charges. Marijuana was supposedly found in his possession, and individuals familiar with Mr. Titiyev say it is far more likely that he participated in the murder of Napoleon than that drugs had been found on him. And unfortunately, this is part of a series of various lawlessness that are happening in Chechnya and which the Memorial organisation, in particular, has suffered. Namely, this arrest of Titiyev was followed by the fact that arson occurred in the Ingushetia capital Nazran in their office and then this violence spread to the Memorial office in Dagestan. We have to defend Titiev because he has received the Sakharov Prize and this is completely illegal.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: author. — Madam President! Dear ladies! The repression meted out by Vladimir Putin's regime at activists of the Memorial Association is an attempt to silence an organisation that has been acting as the conscience of Russia's elites since the collapse of the USSR. It was through the commitment of the Memorial and the immense courage of many of its members that were able to uncover before the public the scale of the crimes of the Soviet communists. The crimes victimized not only by representatives of nations enslaved by Soviet Russia, but also by the Russians themselves, who have not agreed to live in the vast, Moscow-managed eases. Russian authorities directly or through provocation persecute an organization that not only investigates the past, but conducts educational activities, lying off the lies of Soviet propaganda. The case of Ojub Titiyev is one of the latest examples of repression against organizations fighting for human rights in Russia. As in other cases, we must stand firm against this kind of action.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Madam President, I am happy that all Groups are voicing joint concern and protest about the arrest of Memorial representative Oyub Titiev in a place most hostile and deadly to human rights, namely Chechnya. Chechnya was the original base for Putin’s rise to power. And Titiev’s case is not just one more violation of basic human rights. Memorial is a winner of the Sakharov Prize. An attack against this organisation and its representatives is an attack against us – a hostile act against the EU’s highest democratic body.  However, can we hope to have a serious impact on the behaviour of the Russian authorities if our protest is limited to deploring and worrying? Political gangsters value only determination and ability to cause real pain. To make a change, all Member States need to introduce Magnitsky-type lists against those responsible, and we need strong resolve to apply further sanctions if the Russian authorities do not allow free elections and free NGOs.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Madam President, Sergei Kovalev, a prominent Russian dissident, upon receiving the Sakharov Prize in 2009 on behalf of Memorial addressed this very hall with the following words: ‘It is Europe’s duty not to remain silent but, again and again, to repeat and remind, and insist respectfully and firmly that Russia meet its obligations … failure to remind will certainly be understood by the Russian authorities as indulgence’. This was the call of a wise man who spent 10 years of his life in Soviet jails and labour camps. A call more than ever valid today when we see European leaders queuing up for yet another business contract to be blessed by the Kremlin. To maintain and fully implement effective sanctions must be the EU’s response to Russia’s authoritarian elites and their aggressive policy.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Madam President, on 17 January, the office of the Russian human rights NGO Memorial was set on fire. The week before, Mr Titiev, the head of Memorial’s office in Chechnya, was arrested on, according to human rights organisations, fabricated charges of drug possession. According to reports from human rights NGOs, the number of political prisoners in Russia has increased. There is also great concern regarding the human right abuses and torture of LGBTI people in Chechnya. Russian authorities, you have to investigate and stop the assault on human right defenders in Chechnya and in other parts of your country. This is a clear breach of all the international human rights conventions that you have signed. I, as a feminist, find the constant harassment and assault on human rights in Russia unacceptable and the EU cannot ignore these attacks on human rights. We cannot stay silent. The Commission and Member States have to assist those who have fled Chechnya, but also the human rights defenders who are still in Russia.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: author. — Madam President. It sounds like Hollywood, but is bitter seriousness: because of an allegedly defective dipped beam, the police control a person, allegedly finding large quantities of drugs that belong to this person. The arrested person is then allegedly not to be found for their lawyers. In subsequent investigations, an alleged witness does not recognise the alleged perpetrator because of the alleged lack of training of the police protocoler. Stupid, but then the prosecution just makes him a witness himself, and so on and so forth in the script. A stopover reached for the autocrats in Grozny, the capital of a frighteningly lawless area in the middle of the Russian Federation. After the devastation of two wars, this country develops, rebuilds and at the same time seeks itself. The model desired for this by the local head is clear: securing personal absolutist claims with money from Moscow and its own militias and associated state structures. Human rights organisations such as Memorial and people like Ojub Titiyev are interfering with this, of course. It is to be hoped that the people of Chechnya and also Moscow will understand that freedom of justice has never brought stability. Because where vivacity requires it, it only stands for standstill.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Madam President, in 2009, after the brutal assassination of his colleague, Natalia Estemirova, Oyub Titiev became the director of the office of the Human Rights Centre Memorial in Chechnya, and did not give in to pressure that it was most reasonable to shut down this office, given the crimes and abuses that activists from the human rights activists. human rights and journalists were subjected to in that region. It takes a lot of courage, day by day, to defend the most basic freedoms in Chechnya, because Ramzan Kadyrov — Putin's protégé — believes in the region he authoritatively runs that civil society and journalists should be agents of his propaganda and personality worship. That is why Oyub Titiev and journalist Zhalaudi Geriev are in prison today, and the offices of the “Memorial” center in a neighboring republic were attacked. It is also for this reason that the assassination of Natalia Estemirova has never been investigated and has never been resolved. I call on the Russian authorities, on behalf of my political group, initiator of this debate, to release Oyub Titiev and to ensure that abuses against the “Memorial” human rights centre on their territory are stopped.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Madam President, the arrest of Oyub Titiev has a very special significance since it is a winner of the Sakharov Prize. Sakharov, who was, as we know, the victim of communist despotism, has become a universal symbol of human dignity and the struggle for human freedom. A winner of the Sakharov Prize carries precisely this dimension with him. He himself is a symbol of freedom, he himself is a symbol of the struggle for human dignity. Your imprisonment, which is totally illegitimate and attractive, must be strongly condemned by this Parliament. But we must, of course, go further and demand the immediate release of a man who has committed no crime other than fighting for human rights, other than fighting for freedom, who was not fighting for the dignity of his fellow citizens. That is why we must make a very clear denunciation of what has been totally unacceptable behaviour on the part of the Russian Federation in the field of human rights in terms of total disregard for fundamental freedoms.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Madam President, today the Russian Federation is ranked 135 on the Democracy Index of The Economist, and Chechen leader Kadyrov is apparently doing everything in its power to secure that position. The latest achievement of this despot installed by the Kremlin is the arrest of Titiev, Department Director of Memorial, an organisation that was awarded the Sakharov Prize in this Parliament in 2009. As head of Memorial in Chechnya and courageous successor to the murdered Natalya Estemirova, Titiev has long been a louse in the fur of Kadyrov. But under constant threat, Titiev continued to work daily for democracy, human rights and a better future for the Chechens — something he pays for today with his freedom. Titiev, ladies and gentlemen, is an example for all of us, and his arrest also affects us very deeply. I call on the Commissioner, the High Representative and all the Heads of State and Government to publicly express their indignation, demand his freedom and increase pressure on the Russian Federation. We cannot allow an important partner such as Memorial to be expelled from Chechnya.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: for the ALDE Group. — Madam President, I consider it unacceptable that an organisation that is engaged in the protection of human rights faces attacks, lawsuits, prison or, in extreme cases, death. All the more so if it is an organization that is used to honor the monument of victims of crimes committed by the communist regime. In the case of Chechnya, in this regard, it is striking how often civil society leaders are blamed, such as in drug offences. It is our duty to draw attention to this situation and it is in place to demand the immediate release of Mr Titiyev and all other political prisoners, whether they are detained in Chechnya or Russia. Thirty years will soon pass since the first war in Chechnya, and it is sad that people in this country continue to live in fear and repression because of their beliefs.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: — Madam President, in 2009 the European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize to the Russian Memorial. His representative at the time would be human rights advocate Sergei Kovalyov. Nine years later, another Memorial official, Oyub Titiyev, was detained and imprisoned under false pretenses. Let me, ladies and gentlemen, recall the winged words of Sergei Kovalyov: “Violation of human rights cannot be an internal matter of any state.” It also applies today, it also applies to Oyub Titiyev. I would like to remind you of the words of another great man, Czech writer Karel Čapek: “It must be constantly repeated that crime is a crime and we must not allow it to be moral order for its time suspended. “Even Čapek's words apply to Oyub Titiyev and also apply to the criminal regime of the so-called Chechen President Ramzan Kadyrov and apply, after all, to the whole imperial policy of today's Kremlin.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, despite a Russian signature on human rights agreements, in practice violations are rampant and the perpetrators often go unpunished. Such violations may well be condoned or sanctioned from very high up. The arrest of Oyub Titiev of Memorial, which is, indeed, a well-respected Sakharov Prize winner and the last independent NGO operating in Chechnya, is a case in point. New laws throughout Russia target NGOs and restrict free speech and freedom of assembly. On top of that, the targeted abuse of the rights of LGBTI people is of particular concern for our Group. We call for Titiev’s unconditional release, as well as the release of all political prisoners. Russia needs to reverse its course towards its people, their NGOs and their opposition representatives. For the EU, too, it is important to take responsibility, to follow the money and, at least, to shelter those who need our protection most.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: — Madam President, the situation of human rights defenders in Russia continues to deteriorate. We must be reminded of the Memorial, which has a respectable activity in the field of human rights. Russia must know that we are following the case of Oyub Titiyev and hold accountable all those who are outrageously intimidating and persecuting Mr Titiyev and the organisation Memorial. We strongly call for his immediate release, the withdrawal of the false accusation and the examination of all modes of intimidation to which the Memorial is exposed in Chechnya and elsewhere. We have nowhere to recede, this is about the lives of specific brave people, and even if we abandon the value debate on human rights, the statistics directly imply that democracy and human rights are directly related with welfare. So ordinary Russians should make order at home in their own interests.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, it is not an enviable position to be the director of a human rights NGO in Chechnya. Beyond trivial things, such as your work and person being continuously discredited by the authorities, or the fact that the organisation you lead could be closed down at any time, you are very likely to end up in prison, and it can also happen that you are shot dead, as the terrible case of Natalya Estemirova shows. In this sense one could say that we should be relieved that the 60-year-old human rights activist Oyub Titiyev only faces 10 years in prison on charges that are, in all likelihood, fabricated. The arrest of Mr Titiyev falls into the clear pattern in which the authorities of the Chechen Republic try to crush all criticism of Ramzan Kadyrov, the Kremlin-backed leader of Chechnya. I hope that the High Representative and the EEAS will give this and all other cases of political persecution the adequate weight they deserve in EU-Russia discussions.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Madam President, I want to join the appearance of my colleagues. Kauza Titiyev is an indictment of Putin's Russian regime. Putin is directly responsible for how human rights in Chechnya are violated, and this is how we need to name it. There is a puppet government in Chechnya that directly falls under the rule of the Kremlin, and I'm just reminding that we recently discussed human rights violations in Chechnya in connection with criminal bullying, by torturing homosexuals in this small country. That is, again, it shows, the face of Putin's regime, which lets the autonomous rulers there commit such atrocities on the territory of Chechnya. It is therefore good that we are adopting this resolution, but we really should keep in mind what is happening in Russia, in all the negotiations of European states with the Russian Federation, and we should permanently point out that Putin and Russia cannot be a solid partner of the European Union in this situation.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank all the speakers for their contributions to this very important debate at this critical time. Unfortunately, it is not the first time that we have discussed here human rights violations in the Russian Federation. In the past 12 months, we have debated in this Chamber: the repression that followed the anti-corruption demonstrations organised on 26 March 2017; the fate of Ukrainian prisoners in Russia; the situation in the illegally annexed Crimean peninsula, and the persecution of LGBT people in Chechnya. Today we are discussing the dire human rights situation in Chechnya, and this time specifically the increased pressure on, and harassment of, human rights defenders in the North Caucasus Russian Republic. The arrest and detention of Oyub Titiev, who is the head of the regional office of the respected NGO Memorial, is the main reason we are here today. The spokesperson for the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy issued a statement on 11 January on the arrest of Mr Titiev, pointing out that it was part of a worrying trend of arrests, as well as attacks on, and the intimidation and discrediting of, independent journalists and human rights defenders who work in Chechnya. Similar cases in the past include those of the journalist Zhalaudi Geriev and the Chair of the Assembly of the Peoples of the Caucasus, Ruslan Kutaev, who were both sentenced to imprisonment on dubious grounds of drug possession, the same charge now being levelled against Mr Titiev. The case of Mr Titiev is especially of concern, given that his predecessor as head of Memorial in Chechnya, Ms Natalia Estemirova, was killed in 2009 and no one has been brought to justice for that crime. Mr Titiev’s arrest was quickly followed by an arson attack on the Memorial office in neighbouring Ingushetia and by an attack on one of Memorial’s cars in Dagestan. It is clear that the arrest and the attacks are part of a concerted assault on human rights defenders working in Chechnya. Sadly, recent statements from the authorities, including from the Head of the Chechen Republic, Ramzan Kadyrov, denigrating the work of human rights defenders, leave us with the fear that these attacks are being orchestrated by the Chechen authorities themselves, as was the case in the persecution of gay men last year. As we have said, we expect the federal and regional authorities in the Russian Federation fully to observe Mr Titiev’s legal rights, in accordance with Russia’s international human rights commitments, and to release him swiftly. It is time for the Russian authorities to call to order the Chechen leadership and ensure that abuses stop once and for all. Let me conclude by confirming our strong support for the Russian human rights community and independent civil society, and in particular for those working in the most difficult conditions, in terms of human rights violations, in Chechnya. We will continue urging the Russian authorities at all levels to ensure that human rights defenders can continue their work unmolested in all regions of Russia, including Chechnya.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on executions in Egypt (2018/2561 (RSP)).

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: author. – Madam President, Egypt has gone through several difficult challenges since the 2011 revolution, and the international community is supporting the country in its economic, political and security challenges. Frequent terrorist attacks, for example on the Sinai Peninsula, and all other acts of terrorism against Egypt, as well as the constant attacks on Christian Copts, imply a worrying development. Nevertheless, this cannot be an excuse for the Egyptian authorities to continue carrying out capital punishment, which is inhuman and degrading. I am seriously concerned about the mass trials conducted by Egyptian courts and the large number of death sentences. I urge the Egyptian authorities to put an immediate and definitive end to such practices and to reverse the death sentences that have been handed down. I call on the authorities to establish immediately an official moratorium on executions, as a first step towards abolition. We, the EU, strongly condemn the use of the death penalty. I call on the Egyptian authorities to stick to their international commitments in the field of human rights.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, as Egypt makes its transition to democracy, it faces a very serious internal security threat, as illustrated by the large number of devastating ISIS terrorist attacks that were seen across the entire country, particularly in the Sinai and aimed at the Copts.  As we have seen in our own countries, finding the balance between ensuring security and honouring civil liberties in these circumstances is always difficult. Nevertheless, we are right to raise our human-rights concerns with such an important international partner. The continuing use of military courts for trying civilians, the reported use of torture to obtain confessions and the increasing use of capital punishment are all causes for grave concern.  Finally, I would like to welcome the calls in the resolution today for further investigation into the killing of Italian researcher and British resident, Giulio Regini, and the call for greater cooperation in this regard from the Egyptian authorities.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Submitter. — (NL) Mr President, the previous speaker mentioned a transition towards democracy in Egypt. That is not how I would describe the situation in that country. The President, who came to power with a coup, has killed at least 23 people over the last few months. The death penalty is something that we as Europe have been opposed to for a very long time. We also remind every country of it every time people are murdered from institutions. That is the case here. And that just before the election, where there's really no serious choice, because you can only vote for Mr. Sisi or a friend of Mr. Sisi's. Mr President, the question raised by the Greens is: why has Vice-President Mogherini not yet condemned this murder by the Sisi government? We're always at the front. Not this time. It is now important for the European Commission to clarify this.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are discussing a country that has crossed all lines in the violation of human rights, to the point that we can no longer speak of the rule of law. Since El-Sisi was in power, Egypt's government has not only begun to commit death sentences again, something that no longer happened under past governments, but also began executing them. As if that weren't enough, in recent months this phenomenon is growing at dizzying rates. This is only the most serious symptom of the shell-tightening of violence and the utter collapse in the values of the rule of law that is being witnessed in Egypt. This is the context in which a compatriot of mine, Giulio Regeni, was kidnapped, tortured and barbarely killed. A citizen of ours who we cannot defend even as dead, because we are too weak to do so or because perhaps the economic interests of partnership with Egypt are too strong. If the Egyptian authorities allowed this to be done to a researcher, conscious that they would have the spotlight of the West on themselves, I can't even imagine the sad fate it touches daily to unarmed Egyptian citizens and at the utter mercy of a despot. What other human rights, what other international norms does Egypt have to violate before the EU and member states start doing anything beyond outrage and debate? Why is the High Representative for Human Rights holding a resigned tone about what is happening in Egypt? Our role as a guarantor of human rights and the rule of law must translate into facts, we are here for that.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Madam President, the repression in Egypt under General Sisi creates a ticking time bomb. Has no one learned from history? On top of stifling dissent, free speech and restricting NGOs, a shocking number of executions – over 2 000 sentenced since 2014 and at least 81 executions carried out – comes on top of these systematic repressions. The circumstances for those facing trial include torture, forced confessions and ill treatment. Yes, Egypt faces security challenges from terrorism, but the answer is never state terror. It is high time that the High Representative as well as Member State leaders speak out and unequivocally condemn these abuses. The silence in fact is deafening. It is interesting to talk about a partnership, but we have to be realistic. If this partnership is not founded on principles that we share, minimum principles and values, then we have to wonder what the added value is, and I think we have to be crystal clear as the EU.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Madam President, today we are debating the executions in Egypt. Capital punishment constitutes a violation of the right to life. It is the ultimate cruel, inhumane and degrading treatment against a human being. No challenges, no circumstances whatsoever can motivate the killing of a human being. The position of the European Parliament is global abolishment. We stand for that. The doubling of executions in Egypt in one year is not an exception. Authoritarian regimes use military courts that have harsher sentences than civilian courts, and they use laws on terrorism to specifically target their activities on human rights defenders. Many have been denied access to lawyers during their trials and they have been forced to confess through torture. They have been put in solitary confinement and they have been denied the most basic privileges. I call on President el-Sisi to immediately stop all executions and to abolish the death penalty in your country. I say to Ms Mogherini, you have to stand up for the values of the European Union and condemn the executions.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. — (FR) Madam President, all NGOs are alerting us. Human rights have never been so violated in Egypt. There are more than 600,000 arrests since the military coup, more than 15,000 civilians tried by military courts, including more than 150 children, over the past three years. Enforced disappearances, judicial executions, confessions under torture are the daily lot. Rights defenders, journalists, LGBTI, NGOs in general are privileged targets, even when they dare come to testify in the European Parliament. The use of the death penalty appears to have no limits. Terrorism, attacks on national security, drug trafficking, murder, rape, kidnapping, the list sent by the Egyptian Embassy is long, far from international standards, it is a real counter-argument. How can democratic elections take place in such a context, when all credible candidates have been rejected? Egypt is sinkering into a state of non-law and the European Union turned its eyes on behalf of a strategic partnership, which remains to be demonstrated.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I think this is a very balanced resolution. It recognises the difficulties Egypt has, especially in relation to ruthless terrorist attacks, where we saw recently attacks on the Coptic Orthodox Cathedral and a mosque in North Sinai killing hundreds and hundreds of people. So in some respects, it may be understandable that the authorities would be over anxious and overreact.
