Nevertheless, it’s not acceptable when you have mass trials, hundreds of crimes eligible for the death penalty, people being kept in prison for a long time before their trial comes up – and of course all of this is in breach of the International Covenant on Political and Civil Rights, especially Article 14. So it is right we should encourage the Egyptians to look at this and to have a moratorium for the death penalty with a view to abolition, while at the same time standing with the Egyptian people in both having trade with them and in the fight against terrorism.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, within the framework of the 2017-2020 partnership with the European Union, Egypt was committed to promoting democracy, fundamental freedoms and rights humans, in line with its Constitution and international norms. This commitment has not been maintained and demonstrated by the numerous sentences and executions, more than twenty in the last month, which led to the death of citizens, first subjected to torture and treatment inhuman and executed without prior notification and with farce trials before military tribunals. During El-Sisi's presidency this tragic bulletin has accelerated unprecedented. The European Union has repeatedly reaffirmed its condemnation against the death penalty and it is clear that it is not possible to build a solid partnership with this country in the light of what is taking place unless, on the altar of Realpolitik, we disinterest ourselves with human rights and become so morally co-responsible for these brutalities. It is clear that we need a clear and precise commitment to change on the part of Egypt and its President, without which a new chapter of this partnership cannot be opened. Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to further emphasise the recidivist behaviour of this regime. We are still waiting for truth and justice for Giulio Regeni, who was murdered two years ago in Cairo. Also from this we measure the lack of credibility of Egypt's current ruling class.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President Today's debate again shows quite exactly that the EU was on the wrong side during the so-called Arab Spring. For all too long, with a blind eye to binoculars, we have agreed to cooperate with forces like the Muslim Brotherhood. The current Egyptian regime is not without flaws, but it is completely out of all proportion to spend so much time debating Egypt when you saw how much silence lowered over European capitals during the very recent riots in Iran and what it was for a response that in eventually came from the EU on that situation. That's why I think the people who are very busy today talking about the death penalty should spend as much energy talking about Iran, China, the United States, but it's not a debate we have here every second-three months. So maybe people should try to put this into perspective and recognise the Egyptian struggle against terrorism that we share with them and which is a concern that we have both here in the European Union and in Egypt.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, after the 2013 coup d'état, there will be presidential elections in Egypt in March; elections where there is possibly no opposition, because candidates have withdrawn for intimidation and arrests. Under the umbrella of the fight against terrorism, all kinds of human rights violations and acts of repression are committed against journalists, civil society and, in particular, against the labour movement, which, in spite of this, continues to regularly organize demonstrations and strikes. A country where twenty-three people have been executed in the last month after having been tried by military courts without any guarantee. Nevertheless, the European Union decided to look the other way and resume relations, despite the flagrant lack of respect for human rights. We therefore demand that the European Union pronounce itself on these violations. Prohibit the export of arms to Egypt and refrain from legitimizing an electoral result obtained without respecting the most basic democratic rights.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Over 2 000 people have been sentenced to death in Egypt over the past four years and at least 81 of them have already been executed. It is feared that the number of executions will continue to rise massively. In addition, the human rights situation in Egypt is dramatically bad: government critics are threatened and arrested — including lawyers, journalists, human rights defenders — and people are arbitrarily arrested and disappeared. UN experts report that prisoners are being systematically tortured. It is shameful how cautious the EU is in the face of the ongoing massive human rights violations in Egypt. The EU-Egypt Partnership Priorities Agreement, adopted in June 2017, contains mutual commitment to human rights standards. But in the face of these massive human rights crimes and a worsening of the situation in Egypt, the EU must not hide behind these fine words, but must really put firm pressure on the Egyptian Government.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it was on 26 December 2017 when fifteen men accused of terrorism were sent to the scaffold by order of an Egyptian military court. El-Sisi's Egypt broke a new record that day, that of the highest number of summary executions in a single day since 1953. Of the condemned, since the general's rise to power, there are only lifeless bodies covered in burns, wounds and mutilation, evident signs of gruesome, brutal and unacceptable torture. The summary killings are intertwined the forced disappearances of journalists, political opponents and mere intellectuals, just like our Giulio Regeni, whose death still remains shrouded by a silence chilling. The murderous gangs of the military do not feel mercy even in front of innocent children, such as Yasser and Hamza, aged 13 and 15, kidnapped in their homes and found dead, a few days later, on a street in their village. The weapons they use are also European weapons. Trade and Realpolitik justify the accomplice silence of our countries? Is this the security and stability cooperation we want with Egypt? I say no! We must raise our voices up, call for an embargo on the export of arms and continue to demand truth and justice for Giulio Regeni and for all the innocent victims of this brutal regime.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! This is not the first time that we have had a debate on the human rights situation with our neighbour Egypt. We should not let up on doing this until the situation has changed significantly. Anything else would be negligent. It is a deceptive and dangerous illusion to believe that stability can be achieved through systematic repression. We are fatefully connected to Egypt; everything that happens in this country has a direct impact on us in Europe. The rule of law, democracy and human rights are the best guarantee of stability. We therefore see with great concern the downright obsessive use of the death penalty and the systematic restriction of freedom of expression and assembly. We call on President Sisi to suspend the imposition of death sentences and to use the forthcoming presidential elections as an opportunity to finally enable democratic alternatives.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, again we are discussing human rights in Egypt. Today we rightly condemn not only the use of the death penalty in Egypt but its escalation under President Sisi. The Egyptian judicial system has many flaws. The young Irishman, Ibrahim Halawa, can testify to that. Between 26 December and 30 January, 26 people were executed, 24 of whom were sentenced by military courts using confessions extracted through torture. Even more disturbing, the lawyers of those executed were not notified in time to lodge appeals, the families of those hanged were not permitted to say goodbye, and many now are still trying to find out how they can reclaim their relative’s body. It is not good enough that we come here and condemn Egypt. We need action. Egypt has human rights obligations under its EU-Egypt Association Agreement and President Sisi’s crack-down on all forms of civil society is undermining stability not increasing it. Egyptian civilians are looking for us to speak up, because they can’t.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, when we debated Egypt last October the Commission outlined the aspirations of the Egyptian people for security, for democracy and economic growth. I had real reservations about the nature of our partnership then, and have even more so now. We raised our concerns about gross human rights violations, but how does the Sisi regime respond? Almost 30 Egyptian civilians executed in a month; 24 sentenced to death by military courts. Therefore my questions to the Commissioner are, will you clearly outline the repercussions if the Egyptian authorities fail to impose an immediate moratorium on the use of death penalty, and review legislation to meet fair trial standards? When will Member States take measures to stop companies selling equipment to Egypt that helps them repress their citizens. And how will we insist that March elections in Egypt are free and fair, and leverage our EUR 11 billion in aid, if we are not even drawing a line in the sand on capital punishment, a key objective of our human rights policy?

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in 2011 thousands of demonstrators in symbolic Tahrir Square in Cairo showed the world the will to fight for democracy and respect for human rights. Seven years later, practically nothing remains of the optimism of those days. On the verge of presidential elections, announced for the end of March, there is a large-scale repressive atmosphere and the persecution of journalists and LGBTI activists and human rights activists. There is an unprecedented number of forced disappearances, confessions obtained under torture, arbitrary trials and, most seriously, an alarming increase in death sentences and executions, especially since President El Sisi came to power. With the justification of the fight against terrorism, the courts issued 186 death sentences in 2017, three times those imposed in 2016, and, last January alone, 22 civilians were hanged after being sentenced to death by military tribunals. Commissioner, the European Union, which is Egypt's first economic partner, must urge the Egyptian authorities to comply with international human rights obligations, strongly condemn the application of the death penalty in that country and call for the suspension of all executions imminent.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we will approve a joint resolution with clear content. In the Third Millennium in no State in the world there can still be torture, summary executions and failure to respect human rights. The EU is Egypt's first economic partner, but we cannot close our eyes to cruel and inhumane treatment. Let's talk about Giulio Regeni, a young researcher barbarely tortured and then killed in Egypt, who was the son of this Europe founded on rights and freedoms that were trampled on. Maybe someone hoped that after a short time everything would be forgotten. But as a European Parliament we do not intend to be silent and we will always and strongly demand that this murder be made clear. The Egyptian authorities after two years have yet to give a clear answer, which must be given to family members, friends of Julius, but also to 500 million European citizens. Otherwise we cannot think that Egypt is still a good partner and a safe destination to go.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I too join my colleagues in objecting to the fundamental inadmissibility of the death penalty and citing those specific cases. I would like to focus on something else in my minute and that's on the role of diplomacy. I think it is within the diplomatic possibilities of the institutions of the European Union to fundamentally press not only on the Egyptian government, but also to open this subject of the inadmissibility of capital punishment in international field. Unfortunately, we do not have too many partners in the international field on this issue and I think it would take the European Union to move this issue on in a fundamental way. And then I would also emphasize some theory of conditionality of continuation of cooperation and support. I think it is necessary, even in this fundamental demand, which is mentioned here across all political factions, to support those States which will somehow show the inadmissibility of capital punishment a certain willingness to cooperate. And then it should also be reflected in our support that we address to them.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Union is definitely following the situation in Egypt very closely. Our position on the death penalty is well known. The European Union opposes capital punishment under all circumstances and I completely agree with you that, for us, it represents an unacceptable denial of human dignity and integrity. At the meeting of the EU—Egypt Subcommittee on Political Matters, Human Rights and Democracy, which took place in Cairo last month, the Union shared its concerns with the Egyptian authorities. This was about the recent execution of more than 20 people, and we reiterated our principled position against the death penalty. We have called on Egypt to commute death sentences whenever possible and to establish a formal moratorium with a view to the abolition of capital punishment. Furthermore, we encourage Egypt to take concrete steps to end military trials for civilians, and, in accordance with international standards for a fair trial, to retry in civilian courts citizens convicted by military courts. At the same time, I would like to mention a number of other issues concerning websites and human rights organisations. The EU raised, in its position for the EU—Egypt Association Council of July 2017, clear concerns regarding the blocking of websites and the ongoing pressure on human rights organisations and defenders. That position was also expressed in the recent EU statement at the Human Rights Council under item 4, as well as during the latest meeting of the EU—Egypt Subcommittee on Political Matters, Human Rights and Democracy, in January. Egypt is a key partner for the EU and a significant regional player. The sustainable stability and security of this country are crucial, not only for all Egyptians but also for the entire region, for the European Union and for our Member States. It is our firm conviction that democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms are crucial for this purpose, especially in the context of the many challenges that Egypt is facing. We appreciate the difficulties and we stand side by side with Egypt in addressing them. This view is based on universal values and we regularly discuss these with our Egyptian counterparts within the framework of the new Egypt partnership priorities that were adopted in July 2017. The protection and promotion of human rights, democracy and the rule of law are guiding principles for EU external action. You can count on us to continue actively to promote and defend these principles in our engagement with Egypt, as we do with all our neighbours and partners around the world. This is the situation, and we are trying hard to exert pressure in relation to these very important issues.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 8 February 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: in writing. — Since 2014, 2116 people have been executed by the regime of General Abdul Fatah al-Sisi, 891 people are still waiting for their execution. It is very fond of the human rights situation in Egypt. Torture, inhumane treatment and executions of minors are just some of the techniques used by the Egyptian government to control tensions in the country. Terror, unrest and crime keep Egypt in a hold. Nevertheless, the application of the death penalty and the misunderstanding of fundamental human rights is under no circumstances allowed for the N-VA. We are therefore concerned about this situation and support the resolution before us, which strongly condemns these practices. We will continue to oppose the death penalty and call on the Egyptian Government to fulfil all its human rights obligations.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on 'Child servitude in Haitia' (2018/2562 (RSP)).

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: author. — Madam President! Haiti is the poorest country of the Western Hemisphere and one of the poorest in the world. As many as 60% of the population live below the poverty line. Unfortunately it's also the country that ranks eighth in the world slavery index. Restavek — for this is what enslaved children are called — are born into poor families in the countryside and are given to rich families with the hope of a better future. Unfortunately that doesn't happen. This future for them is no better. In fact, they are forced to work hard. They are exploited, malnourished, and rarely receive education. The statistics are heartening: every 15th child in Haiti is restavek, 60% of whom are girls. It is unimaginable for such practices to take place in the 21st century, particularly as they affect the most vulnerable — children. That is why in the resolution we condemn the Haitian government for failing to protect those most in need and call for urgent legislation to put an end to this shameful practice. We need to be advocates for these children and stand up for them. I ask you to support this resolution.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: author. — (FR) Madam President, I want to say that Haiti is not a country of crap. It was Mr Trump who described this country, as you know, where we went in December as part of the ACP delegation. On the contrary, it is a very endearing country, where the European Union invests in interesting projects, but where poverty is pervasive. As a result, the situation of young people is terrible because there are between 150,000 and 500,000 young people who suffer slavery within the families themselves. How to respond to this? I fully support this text because it seems to me that it is possible to deal with this problem if poverty is eradicated, because they are very poor families who entrust their children to other families, who are a little less so. To eradicate poverty, we must play on agriculture. The European Union is providing assistance in this regard, but it is often aimed at very large farms and does not reach the small ones who can, in fact, fight poverty. As for the regime in place, I assure you that I have not seen any more rotten than parliamentarians, whether they are senators or members of the National Assembly. It is therefore necessary to redirect EU funds to support education because it also involves education. The more people can be helped to read and write, the easier it will be to get out of poverty.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: author. — Madam President! Modern slavery has many faces. Recently in this room, we discussed the situation of the Haratins in Mauritania. Today, the theme is Haitian restavek — children who come from poor rural families and are passed on, often sold to wealthier families where they work above the force, are victims of violence, have no chance of getting basic education. Almost a fifth of Haitian children between the age of six and eleven do not attend school. This phenomenon has a complex economic and social basis, and the current difficult political situation and lack of action for change in key legislation gives permission for violations of human rights and children's rights. Also, the lack of a birth record system exposes children to being victims of human trafficking. The Haitian authorities must introduce measures to tackle the problem of child slavery, especially as part of the reform of the penal code. Implementing the registration system of all newborns and regulating the situation of unregistered children, as well as providing adequate support for victims of domestic slavery is also crucial.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: author. – Madam President, heaven knows Haiti has its problems. Years of corruption, natural disasters and earthquakes would test any country, so what is unique to Haiti? What is holding them back?  My first speech to this House was after the 2010 earthquake, when children were being sold into slavery. But today we still see the terrible plight of children there. Haiti has half a million children at risk, in slavery and being trafficked. The Haiti custom known as restavek holds the most vulnerable children as slaves and servants for host families. So what is the Haitian Government doing to protect these children? Well, when a government’s budget puts more into cleaning offices than providing health services, you know something is wrong. Corruption is endemic and this has to change. Poverty, unemployment, poor health services and lack of education must cease to be the reality for Haitians. After all, on the other side of the island, in the Dominican Republic things are not so bad. So it cannot just be geography. The children of Haiti deserve care, education and protection from their Government. This House needs to send a strong signal, and I urge you, colleagues, to support this motion.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: author. — Madam President, Haiti is a broken country. It is a country broken by slavery, it is a country broken by poverty, colonization, occupation and illegitimate debt. It is also a country broken by misery, natural accidents, disasters, pests. And it's a country broken by its political and economic class, which is the most predatory I've ever seen in my life in any country in the world. It is true, therefore, that the country suffers and suffers from poverty and, when poverty is suffered, boys and girls suffer the most. The phenomenon of restaveks — hundreds of thousands of enslaved children — is intolerable, unbearable. But that is why we have to support Haiti and not the opposite. That is why the message to all those who now want to reduce aid to the Haitian country is the opposite: more aid, more confidence in the new Haitian Government that is making the way to strokes against all elements, among others, against a totally predatory economic class. To put an end to the restaveks, the Haitian Government must be supported.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Author. — (PT) Madam President, Haiti is an impoverished country, devastated and also drowned by the debt imposed by France and other international institutions. It also faces a serious food insecurity situation. Children are the main victims. We propose that the Haitian authorities ratify ILO Convention 189 and ensure that slavery, child exploitation and sexual violence are put to an end, paying particular attention to domestic work, because it is certainly the most invisible, that development aid should not be used to pressure the ILO to ratify the Association Agreement with the European Union, that European aid be granted in the form of a donation and for France to repay the colonial debt. And finally, respect for Haiti's right to food sovereignty, supporting peasants and peasants to produce food for their people.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: for the PPE Group. — Madam President, it is estimated that about thirty thousand children live in orphanages in Haiti. But few people know that 80% of these children have at least one parent. What is the reason that these kids are there? The main reasons are economic. This country, as already mentioned here, has gone through an earthquake. She has gone through two great hurricanes over the past year, and a number of parents simply don't have the money to take care of their children. And here is our task as MEPs, Europeans, European Union to appeal to the authorities in Haiti. First of all, to the state administration to start doing something about this situation. In 2015, although it set up an office to address this situation, it does not adequately use its competence. And that's why I'm glad we have a fairly strong commissioner here who can do something about this situation, and I believe he will help Haitians change this situation.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner. I think it is very important that this issue is being discussed today in the European Parliament. The Restavek, the child slaves in Haiti, do not have a lobby. There are few NGOs that take care of their fate. That is why I am pleased that we are putting this at the centre of the debate today. Haiti deserves support after the earthquake and because of its great poverty, which continues to prevail in the country. But we, as the EU, also have opportunities, and we must use them. We give a budget support, which is good, which gives confidence in the government. But the government must also justify this confidence by focusing more on education, so that the spending of Haiti will be better concentrated there. This includes getting the children's registration, which includes ensuring that regular school attendance can take place. I believe that these are the first steps and we, as the EU, must continue to follow this.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I am appalled that we even have to have a global slavery index. Slavery is something that should not exist anymore. Even more saddening is the situation in Haiti, with child slavery ranking high. One in 15 children lives as a restavek in Haiti, and 60% of these are girls. Many of them are also sexually abused. It is a consequence of the huge amount of poverty in Haiti. The international community can, and must, help the Haitians in their fight against poverty and help them make education accessible to each child’s biological family, all over the country. It is imperative to see that resources are spent on community-based services to strengthen the ability of families and communities to care for their own children. The legislation must be put in place to detect and investigate child slavery cases, traffickers must be brought to justice and labour laws must be updated to address child labour. The European Union can also help Haiti to break free from its cycle of extreme vulnerability to natural disasters and make it more resilient.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, Haiti, the most populous country in the Caribbean, is also the poorest and most unequal in all the Americas. Extreme poverty and the vulnerability of the population are marked by a highly dependent and extremely indebted economy. In this scenario, as always, women, and boys and girls, are the most affected. It is socioeconomic conditions that lead thousands of minors into slavery and we are in the 21st century, in 2018, and we are here, in this house, talking about child slaves. Until we effectively address the issue not only of poverty, but of inequality — and that means redistribution — Haiti will never be resilient. There is also an urgent need to address that unsustainable and illegitimate debt. The European Union as the main donor plays a key role. But without an effective development policy accompanied by external action coherent with it, many urgent resolutions we make will not achieve anything. Let us use our strength to push this Government to ratify and implement the essential conventions on the fight against slavery and trafficking in minors. Let us use our strength to strengthen good governance and that savagery like this will no longer happen. As Mr Neuser said, these boys and these girls have no lobby in here to defend them.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (FR) Madam President, while the Republic of Haiti is ravaged by poverty, corruption and trafficking in children, the European Union has allocated €420 million to finance mainly nutrition and child education programmes. The first thing to do is to verify that these funds are strictly used for this purpose in order to improve the lot of children. Unfortunately, it is not enough for the European Union, which has no legitimacy for this, to order the political actions to be carried out in that country so that they can take place. On the contrary, interference can have adverse consequences, much worse for the most fragile. Combating child slavery will be the early ratification by as many States of all international instruments relating to economic and social rights and protection against enforced disappearance, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, all of us who have been among the parliamentarians in Haiti have left some of our hearts in this country as well. Misery calls its lot of miseries and, unfortunately, it is always the weakest who pay, especially the children. So, what should I do? On the one hand, I believe that the State should be supported in its rural development and education policies. It was the basis for the development of this country that once was the world's leading exporter of sugar. So, with double key to be sure of assignment: on the one hand, the state and, on the other, the representatives of the European Union. On the other hand, we must use our financial capabilities: 4 trillion billion have been created in the European Union through monetary creation, 18 trillion billion in the world, and not one euro in the development economy. It is absolutely necessary to launch a Marshall plan for development.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: — Sinjura President, is-sistema restavek Fil-aiti, li tuża t-tfal bressa ala to addiema, hija forma inaettabbli u intollerabbli tas-skjavitù u t-traffikar tat-tfal. Din hi kawża ta' faqar estrem f'wieiheed mill-aktar pajjiżi foqra fid-dinja. Fil-forom kollha tiegЂu, it-tfunaddim tat-tfal jagallowmel for a kbira lill-istess tfal u jxekkel l-edukazzjon u l-iżvilupp tag-hom. Immam dak li qed jito ri fil- Huwa skjavitù tat-tfal li jolqot wieed minn hawk yummistax-il tifel u tifla fil-aiti, fejn 60% minnhom huma bniet. Aktar minn 300,000 tifel u tifla, b- alissa, jinsabu fi skjavitù bЂala restaveks fil-aiti. Din hija's envelope enerazzjon futura tal-aiti li suppost gandha taqla' lill-pajjiż mill-faqar, iżda minflok [ma] qed jiЂu edukati u offruti futur b'dinjità u tama gЂal gaajja aajar, qed jizarati użati bala skjavi. Il-problema hi illi s-sistema restavek gandha l-geruq tagthe fil-kultura tal-aiti u sothe jalment hija a Nemmen li s-soluzzjon biex tissolva l-kwistjon ta' restaveks tinsab f'idejn il-poplu tal-aiti stess, però nemmen li L-unjoni Ewropea u L-Istat membri gandhom is-sathe the the li jwasslu gShoal bidla politika biex ma ninjorawx il-wegx il-wegx diet tago u ngthe inu lill-pajjiż biex jegleb lil dawn l-isfidi.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: – Madam President, it is sad that nowadays we are still witnessing not just slavery but its most heinous and awful form, child slavery. In Haiti poor parents from rural areas send their children away under the illusion that they will be educated and well kept and will have brighter opportunities in life. Restaveks are, in fact, exploited physically and verbally abused, whipped, humiliated and sometimes sexually exploited. Moreover, children live in precarious conditions of health and nourishment. Often prevented from going to school, they are forced to work 18—20 hours per day. Every time a restavek implores to be sent back home, he or she is likely to receive a beating in return. At the end of this nightmare these undefended children will end up on the street. The two major factors that perpetuate the restavek system are widespread poverty and a social acceptance of the practice. Therefore, I wish to invite the European Union and the Member States to increase their financial support to the Haitian Government on condition that it complies with the obligation to respect the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the worrying landscape of human rights violations there is a specific category, which is perhaps the most insidious and worrying of all, I am referring to violations that touch the lives of children. Of all they are certainly the worst, because they have a devastating impact on the person the child will become, thus condemning not only his present, but also his future and therefore the future of the whole country in which they take place. In Haiti, the term restavek is used to describe the condition of a child who was born into a poor family and is literally sold to a different family, often in the city. This condition, which affects as many as 40 000 Haitian children, is turning into a form of modern slavery. 95% of these little slaves suffer physical and psychological mistreatment and 25% of little girls are subjected to sexual assault before the age of 18, and all in the corrupt silence of the ruling class. We need to put an end to this aberrant practice. The Haitian authorities must ratify and comply with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the European Union must provide maximum support to the very poor Caribbean island, supporting the fight against poverty and for literacy. The moral sense of a society is measured on what it does for its children.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the debate. We're all describing the horrors that are happening in Haiti to children, however, if the debate is to have any outcome and it's not only supposed to be Count Councils, then really the conclusion of the debate should be that The European Union, the Commission will be really much more to help these children on this island, because we all know that the cause is poverty, the turmoil of this country due to natural conditions, the hurricane and in short and well this country, even if it wanted to, will not be able to solve the problems of children in slavery. So the only chance we can do anything about it is that we will help much more, look back where the €420 million will go, whether they will help the children or whether the money will be broken down. Further, we need to press other partners in the world who promised Haiti aid after the hurricane. That means, that help has to come from the outside, then there's a chance the kids in Haiti will do better.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, Commissioner Stylianides, last December the meeting of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly took place in Haiti, the poorest country in Latin America, devastated not only by misery but also by catastrophes and hurricanes, and we knew firsthand this dramatic, terrible situation: 300 000 minors dragged into child slavery, are completely lacking in social rights, health rights, but also food and the most basic education. It is therefore a situation which seriously appeals to the European Union's development and humanitarian cooperation policy. Because it is a moral and political imperative of the first magnitude that the European diplomatic and cooperation effort in Haiti aims to combat not only child poverty, but also the humiliation, abuse and slavery to which all these children in Haiti are currently subjected.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I support the resolution, which I endorse. It is a resolution condemning child slavery in Haiti, a country which is particularly poor and with a huge external debt, which is soon to be restructured. The use of children as domestic workers - restavek, as they are called - in Haiti is a system, in fact, of modern slavery. This is about the marketing of domestic workers. Over 400,000 children in Haiti are part of this system, and 60% are girls. Most of them have suffered sexual violence. It is obvious that this unacceptable situation must be put an end to it. The Haitian Government must be forced to sign UN Convention 189 and concrete measures must be taken to protect children in order to abolish this system of modern child slavery.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in Haiti, between 150 and 500 000 children between 7 and 14 years old, the vast majority of them girls, are loaned by their parents to families who employ them in domestic chores, under conditions of real servitude. They are prevented from going to school, they are burdened with work and subjected to physical, verbal and sexual violence, and often victims of international networks of trafficking and prostitution of children. It is a sad irony that the country where the first abolition of slavery in history took place, and the only one whose independence started a revolt of enslaved, maintains the tradition of the Restavek in the 21st century. Today this authentic form of modern slavery continues to be culturally accepted thanks to the extreme poverty of the population, especially rural ones. The absence of social services and free public schools has worsened further after the devastating earthquake of 2010 and the natural disasters that followed it. Commissioner, the European Union must condemn this unworthy situation and call on the Haiti authorities to harmonise their domestic legislation with international obligations on human rights and the rights of the child and to put an end to the impunity with which child trafficking networks operate in that country.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, Commissioner. Child slavery is a terrible story. But we are closing our eyes to a significant part of the problem, and we are making it too easy for us to attribute this now to the fact that the country is so horribly poor. There are many poor countries in the world where there is no child slavery. We must also name the real leaders, and the real leaders of this terrible child slavery, that is the country's leading elite, that is the country's political and economic leadership elite, and we must tackle them at the portepee and remind them of their responsibility. If that's no use, then we have to apply coercive measures. We introduced travel restrictions for the Russian leadership elite when Russia broke international law in Ukraine. Why not introduce travel restrictions for the Haitian leadership elite if it breaks human rights in such blatant ways or tolerates human rights being violated? We need to act more decisively than just lamenting poverty. We need concrete action, and they need to be addressed to the country's leading elite.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I would like to say that this is such a vicious cycle, poverty, corruption, lack of education, lack of paid work, tragic health and, in fact, a dysfunctional state, which finds itself in ruins even as a result of multiple natural disasters. Slavery, of course, is fundamentally inadmissible, whatever it is called, however, in Haiti, there seems to be a kind of direct connection precisely between poverty and that slavery. I agree with my colleague Luck that the government is responsible for this situation, but I am not sure if we are to impose sanctions or open this issue at all because of whom these sanctions will turn out, first and foremost it will be those kids. And I think that the only chance is really more to guard the money we send to Haiti, to work with independent non-state organizations on this issue, and to actually guard this money, because only then can we bring at least some benefit to those groups concerned.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I reiterate the calls for the European Union to contribute as best as it can to the Haitian Government’s efforts to improve the extremely troubling living conditions of children in Haiti. It is crucial to protect vulnerable minors from abuse and to have more community values that foster a stable and safe environment for children. I welcome the call for effective mechanisms in Haiti to establish protection for children who may fall victim to abuse and child labour as a result of the restavek system, whereby hundreds and thousands of children are sent to families other than their own. Most of them don’t go to primary school. One in four girls and one in five boys become victims of sexual abuse before 18 years of age, and 85% of children are subject to violent discipline. This is a result of the social norms that exist there, and I think that we must work hard to ensure that those social norms are cast aside. I also agree that we should be increasing, not decreasing, humanitarian development aid to Haiti.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the protection of children’s rights is a top priority in our external action worldwide, in particular in development and humanitarian aid. We have been actively engaged in the fight to end child labour, boost access to education and, of course, strengthen children’s rights. I totally agree with you regarding the powerful role of education in such difficult conditions on the ground, and that is why, as Commissioner, from the beginning of my term of office I decided to increase our budget for education in emergencies eight times. It is quite important to realise that sometimes, in such conditions, education is the only way to protect children. In this regard, Haiti is no exception. The Haitian population – and in particular, the most vulnerable groups, including children – have been particularly affected by natural disasters and instability. We are also fully aware of the so-called restavek practice, which exposes children to exploitation, sexual abuse and isolation, condemning them to illiteracy and perpetuating poverty. The European Union is very sensitive to these major human rights issues and that is why among our top priorities for cooperation with Haiti is the promotion of education and human rights, with several programmes under the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR) aimed at fighting these practices, which are shameful, frankly speaking. Children’s rights are also one of the priority issues for the periodical EU political dialogue with the Haitian authorities. We, as the European Union, clearly intend to maintain and further increase our involvement in this issue. At the most recent political dialogue, which took place in Port-au-Prince on 30 January, we conveyed our concern regarding the precarious situation of children and their rights. In particular, we reiterated the need to follow up on the latest Universal Periodic Review recommendation in this regard.  Two EU projects, each worth EUR 0.5 million, have been approved: one focusing on access to justice and legal protection for children, and the other dealing with the protection of children in urban areas near the border with the Dominican Republic where, unfortunately, there is a higher incidence of child trafficking. These projects will be implemented until 2020. The European Union will also continue to advocate the ratification and effective implementation of relevant international conventions such as the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention 182 on the Worst Forms of Child Labour, and ILO Convention 138 on the Minimum Age for Admission to Employment. These are our activities in order to alleviate the suffering of children in Haiti. Thank you for your attention.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. — At both national and international levels, strict compliance with the standards of protection of children's rights must be ensured. Haiti must take effective and immediate measures to prevent child trafficking, slavery, exploitation, coercion or any other non-human treatment. The younger generation is the foundation and future of society, and quality education, health measures, recruitment and other guarantees necessary for personality development must be guaranteed. The Haitian state urgently needs a sustainable legal framework and strict enforcement of these norms in order to restore the country's socio-economic situation, prevent child trafficking and slavery, riots, unrest, increased crime levels and the humanitarian crisis. I stress that it is of particular importance for Haiti to develop international cooperation in the field of human rights in order to prevent child slavery for maintenance as soon as possible, to obtain the opportunity to provide rehabilitation measures to victims in order to restore their emotional, psychological state and to guarantee further harmonious development.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Before we start our voting session, I have to make two announcements and I would like to have your attention. The first announcement is related to the Taiwan earthquake. At the resumption of this plenary sitting, our thoughts go out to the victims of the powerful earthquake in Taiwan yesterday, some of whom are still missing. We wish the victims, their families and the emergency workers, who are still working round the clock to help as many people as possible, every strength in the aftermath of this natural disaster.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The second announcement is that the competent authorities of France have notified the election to the European Parliament of Jacques Colombier, with effect from 2 February 2018, replacing Edouard Ferrand. I welcome our new colleague and remind him that he takes his seat in Parliament and on its bodies and enjoys all the rights attaching thereto under the conditions laid down by the regulation. ***

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, I note that we are discussing the European Investment Bank, but we have not discussed the fact that the British are owed 35 billion and we would like our money back. That means that all the stuff they are talking about is irrelevant and it has to be looked at again.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: – Mr President, I would say that there is inflation in the number of cases in which this House votes to enter into negotiations on the basis of a mandate that is put to the vote in committee and not in plenary, and that is problematic. It is, of course, reasonable if there is a broad consensus in the relevant committee on the substance, but, in this case, on the most important parts of this matter, there were only three votes that made the difference. That is not enough. There should also be a reflection of what is voted on in committee and in other opinion-giving committees, which again is not the case here, as the outcome does not reflect, for example, the Transport Committee’s vote. Essentially the issue is, of course, less about how much information truck users should give away to help us know how much CO2 emissions they produce and more about how much information they should give away so that Chinese competitors can get their upper edge. The principal question, which is probably more important, is that the European Parliament plenary should decide on the mandate for the European Parliament to enter into negotiation and should not regularly delegate that decision to the Environment Committee, or any other committee for that matter. Therefore we should vote against entering negotiations on the basis of this mandate without scrutinising it. (Applause)

name: Helga STEVENS
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, firstly, Mr Dalton apologises that he is unable to be here to speak on this report himself. This regulation is an important step to close loopholes and improve cooperation between Member States in the fight against criminality. The efficient exchange of information on previous criminal convictions in the EU Member States is vital, in order to ensure trust, confidence and mutual recognition in the area of judicial cooperation. It is also only right that there is equality in the exchange of information on convictions of EU nationals and third-country nationals. Today, under the current European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS), we identify previous criminal convictions in the EU for EU nationals but not for third-country nationals. Our report closes this gap. The report had wide support in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) precisely because it provides a fair balance between protecting the rights of individuals and ensuring that past criminal convictions are correctly attributed. It is about ensuring that judicial authorities and law enforcement agencies have a complete picture in order to carry out their work. As an instrument it offers clear safeguards and protection. It is only for convictions handed out by EU Member States, and it can be accessed only under certain very specific circumstances. A robust and secure system for sharing conviction information with clear safeguards is needed, and this is what the LIBE Committee has proposed.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: Mr President, this is a point of order at the table. We have already brought this issue here to the plenary. We are speaking on a report that is presented to Members of this House only in a language version, in English. This is a clear violation of the principle of multilingualism, which also stems from what are the cuts that this House has approved, particularly in the translation mechanisms. It is unacceptable to pronounce Members in a document that is presented only in one language.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: As I was reminded, we are now deciding on the decision of the committee and not on the text as such.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, in paragraph 8, which deals with political pressure on journalists, I propose to add one sentence: Urges Turkey to drop charges against a Finnish-Turkish journalist, Ayla Albayrak, who has been convicted by the Turkish court in absentia.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The vote is over.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: — Mr President, the creation of a Guarantee Fund for External Action is part of the European External Investment Plan. In addition to the European Fund for Strategic Investments and Support for Investment Projects outside the Union, the Guarantee Fund is the third pillar of this External Investment Plan. Overall, up to €44 billion of investment in Africa and the EU's neighbourhood should be mobilised under it. When it comes to the Guarantee Fund, its purpose is to act as a budget guarantee for third countries in order to avoid insolvency. I agree that the Commission has a guarantee fund in its report. I have confidence in her staffing capacity and staff expertise. At the same time, this transfer from the European Investment Bank will save the fees that would otherwise have been paid to it. On the other hand, I am of the opinion that the Commission must be open to scrutiny to the European Parliament and the Court of Auditors. I believe that the Commission will manage the Guarantee Fund on the basis of the principles of a good farmer.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: — Mr President, recent years have been marked by several climate disasters and armed conflicts that have set millions of people in motion. The refugee and migration crisis has its roots beyond the borders of the European Union, so it is very important that we address its causes on the ground. For this reason, I support the establishment of investment projects outside the Union within the framework of an external investment plan. Through the European Investment Bank, we invest in projects promoting sustainable development and inclusive economic growth. Projects funded by the external investment plan must focus on a long-term development programme, which means addressing the root causes of migration. The local private sector must also be included in this. These are local businesses, local people in the hard-tested countries of Africa, the Middle East or Asia, who must learn to fight poverty, hunger and conflict. And to that end, I am also setting up an external investment plan that should be a catalyst for sustainable growth and job creation.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report by Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial on the annual report of the European Investment Bank has the merit of being sure to be complete. I agree in principle on the potential of the EIB to improve the economic situation within the European Union, and I refer to the soft loans provided to small and medium-sized enterprises, potential of the same in our neighbourhood. However, I had already pointed out in the Committee on Regional Development the problems related to the EIB's high-risk operations, so-called special activities. In essence, part of our balance sheet guarantees, through financial engineering, the EIB's most at-risk operations, protecting private investors. Again, privatization of profits and publicization of losses in full crisis. I recognise that great importance is given to mechanisms for avoiding funding to companies that carry out tax fraud, but I would have liked the report to address more boldly, the lack of transparency as regards access to data on projects financed by the EIB. Finally, we had tabled a series of amendments to condemn the involvement of the EIB in financing major infrastructure projects with high environmental impact, such as the TAP. I would like to point out here, Mr President, that our position arises from sharing those same principles that the EIB is concerned with and which then disproves in fact. The implementation of the TAP not only violates the precautionary principle, which everyone in this House seems to share only in words, but above all the aspirations of the bank, which I remember to be investments responsible at social and environmental level. I do not see in the realization of another monstrous work, with disastrous environmental and social impacts, a choice nor a responsible investment. For this motivation, our vote was abstention.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report. The far snazzier 378 new carriages for trains in East Anglia is thanks to EUR 60 million from the European Investment Bank, the amazing facilities at Stanford-le-Hope superport in London Gateway (EUR 100 million), the Galloper Wind Farm off the Suffolk coast (EUR 225 million), and schools across Luton and Hertfordshire, like Westfield Academy in Watford (EUR 63 million). That is what being part of the European Investment Bank has meant for the East of England, and I say ‘long may it continue’. I hope that the UK Government takes note that the Investment Bank’s AAA credit rating is higher than its own and so prioritise Britain’s continuing to maintain the closest possible relationship into the future, so that our companies can continue to finance big-ticket infrastructure projects.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: — Mr President, the European Investment Bank plays a positive role in mitigating public investment shortages. I want to appreciate that, in the social sector, it lends an average of 1 billion a year for social housing projects, 1.5 billion for health infrastructure and 2.4 billion euros for educational infrastructure projects. On the contrary, the EIB, as a public financial institution that finances projects aimed at implementing EU policies and priorities, should also contribute to economic, social and territorial cohesion, including less developed regions. However, the EIB's Financial Activities Report shows that up to 54,11% of all loans granted in 2016 received the five most economically strong Member States. I therefore join the call for the EIB and the Commission to examine the causes of this situation and to inform the EP about them while taking measures for a wider territorial distribution of funds in order to reduce regional disparities.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, I have always been a supporter of Turkey, including its attempt to join the European Union, but I have to say that even I am gradually changing my mind because what is going on in Turkey these days is simply crossing a red line. We see that gradually democracy in this country is being curbed. We see political pressure on free media, on the judiciary, on state administration, on the school system and universities. We see various strange conspiracy theories being spread around and we see also a gradual departure from the secular character of the State. I think that it is time, therefore, to call particularly on the ruling party to stop this and therefore such a resolution is fully justifiable, and I supported it.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, I am glad that I have colleagues from the ECR who share this vision. I voted for this resolution on the condemnation of Turkey and, moreover, we have had this constant speech over the years since Erdogan introduced the dictatorship. Thousands of people have been displaced and several hundred have been killed since the beginning of the Turkish Government's military incursion against Kurdish militia into the Afrin enclave in northwestern Syria. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights estimates that 67 Syrian citizens have been killed as a result of this military operation. Of these 67, 20 are children. The situation is very serious and deteriorating. The Turkish government is determined to violate any international obligation, any international treaty, ignores the fact that it is a member of the UN, so I do not believe that diplomatic talks will be able to achieve a positive conclusion. I remind you that the Netherlands recently interrupted diplomatic relations, froze diplomatic relations with Turkey, saying that at this time it is not the case to maintain diplomatic relations. All Member States should do this.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I supported the resolution on human rights in Turkey, but I want to focus on Afrin, where Turkey is justifying its intervention as self-defence against terrorism. Yet there has been no attack from Afrin on Turkey. This is a blatant violation of international law, with Turkish bombs targeting hospitals, civilians and children. Turkey is even teaming up with the Jihadist militia to kill Kurdish fighters, who have been our key allies in pushing back the Daesh.  Language used by authorities on social media reeks of ethnic cleansing, leaving little room for doubt about the Turkish agenda, and this is yet another blow to the Geneva process. We need to break silence on the Turkish invasion –  not only in the UN, but also in NATO – ensure humanitarian access to Afrin and put this high on the agenda of the upcoming Syria Donor Conference, and adopt a leading role on Syria, bringing the Geneva process back to the forefront and making the EU strategy adopted last year worth its name.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tacaím go hiomlán leis an dtuairisc seo. Is páirtnéir tábhachtach don Aontas Eorpach í an Tuirc agus mar thír iarrthóra tá uirthi caighdeán árd daonlathais a choimeád.  Táim buartha faoin nós atá sa Tuirc ball de lucht an fhreasúra dhaonlathaigh, iriseoirí, cosainteoirí na gceart daonna, dlíodóirí, ionadaí den tsochaí shibhialta agus fir agus mná léinn a chur sa phríosún. Tá tuairiscí á dtabhairt mar gheall ar an drochíde a thugtar do na bpríosúnaigh seo agus ar an gcéasadh a dhéantar orthu. Níl meas dá laghad ar shaoirse creidimh agus tá an t-ardú san idirdhealú in aghaidh na gCríostaithe go huafásach ar fad. Muna n-athróidh an Tuirc go luath, ní féidir léi, ná an tAontas a bheith dáiríre faoina stádas mar thír iarrthóra chun a bheith ina bhall den Aontas Eorpach. Tá súil agam go dtiocfaidh athrú ar an scéal go luath sa Tuirc.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe it is absolutely positive that the European Parliament has expressed all its concern about the deterioration of human rights in Turkey, to the detriment of academics, to the harm of journalists, to the detriment of opposition. First hand I was able to see in Ankara, where I went in December to try to attend the trial of the two co-chairs of the HDP, what is the seriousness of this denial, international delegation was barred from attending the processes. I add that the resolution is not enough though. We must call for the PKK to be removed from the list of terrorist organisations and we must solidarise with Rojava, with Kurdish women, and we must seriously condemn, without ifs and buts, what the Turkish government is doing in Afrin.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: –Mr President, as we all know, Turkey is becoming less and less respectful of human rights. At the same time it is becoming a more and more important regional power and its every political move may have severe repercussions on security in Europe. Erdoğan is able to justify any human rights repressions and the use of brutal force as a pretext for fighting terrorism and the desire for revenge for the failed attempted coup in 2016.  This strategy means that we are probably going to see even more crackdowns on civil society in the months to come. What is even more worrying is that the international community is going to have less information on what really happens in Turkey. I have a journalistic background and I can personally testify to the crucial importance of free mass media in a country’s political trajectory. Current persecutions, jailing and physical attacks on journalists is unacceptable. That is why I voted in favour and sincerely hope that corresponding political decisions by the Member States will follow.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution on the current human rights situation in Turkey as I am deeply concerned about the situation. The government’s repressive measures under the state of emergency are disproportionate and they breach the basic rights and freedoms enshrined in international conventions to which Turkey is a state party.  The lack of respect for the freedom of religion and increased discrimination against Christians is as worrying as the imprisonment of a large number of members of the democratic opposition and journalists like the German, Deniz Yucel, human rights defenders like peace activist, Osman Kavala, lawyers, civil society representatives and nearly five thousand academics in Turkey.  I expect a candidate country to uphold the highest standards of democracy, including respect for human rights, the rule of law, fundamental freedoms, such as the freedom of expression and freedom of assembly and association, as fundamental pillars of any democratic society.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: — Mr President, the situation in Venezuela is serious, it deserves our attention, it deserves our criticism. Indeed, we have commented on the state of human rights and democracy in different countries. As for Venezuela, we have here a specimen example of actually the crash of real socialism, respectively, the Latin American version of it. The crash of the nationalized economy and the crash of central management. And we also have an example of a certain hypocrisy in particular of the left part of the political spectrum of this parliament, which, if I remember correctly, was very critical of the situation in Colombia, because there was a right-of-center government ruling, so Colombia was shelled from various political positions. There was an effort to even block the negotiation or ratification of a free trade agreement with Colombia, and now all of a sudden when we have a similar case here in Venezuela, the European left is in this the parliament has gone quiet. I think it's rather hypocritical that you need to measure everyone by the same meter.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Mr President, while Venezuela has already been countless declarations, resolutions and, at last, the interference of this Parliament, in Honduras are still waiting for this house to pronounce and condemn the more than forty murders by the police forces, the more than two hundred wounded and the more than 1,000 arrests, militarization of the streets and the suppression of fundamental freedoms. All this after a very dubious elections — the European Union knows this — from which a government that is illegitimate has emerged. And that is not what I say, says the Honduran Constitution, which expressly prohibits re-election. With our silence we will be securing a regime that has all institutions abducted, including the judiciary, the electoral tribunal and the security forces; a regime that cannot be called democracy. The Honduran people bleed out while the world looks the other way. What are we waiting for in this house to demand that the Government of a trade and development partner like Honduras stop killing and repressing its people? Let us be coherent and demand human rights and democratic values in all parts of the world alike. The Honduran people can't wait any longer. Human rights have no political color, do they have it?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you, although it was not on Venezuela.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, in Venezuela, President Maduro replaced parliament with a puppet construction, through which he basically wants to concentrate all his powers in his hands. Further, the president announced presidential elections in April, but banned the candidacy of his real opponents. So again, there will be some phantom choices, made specifically for him to win back. Moreover, the Caracas executive used force brutally and repeatedly against citizens who went out to the streets to claim their rights. In 2017, we have reports that more than 120 people died, several thousand were injured and more than 300 were imprisoned for political reasons. Inflation above 4 000% has actually turned the economic crisis in Venezuela into a humanitarian crisis, and we are dealing with a situation of food security. We cannot tolerate this, and we must help the people, but not the government.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Venezuela. We must stand together with the Venezuelan people in their fight for human rights and democratic ruling of the country. We condemn the decision of the illegitimate National Constituent Assembly to call early presidential elections by the end of April 2018. It is of the utmost importance to continue imposing EU sanctions and in particular to extend them to the main perpetrators responsible for the increased political, social, economic and humanitarian crisis, namely President Nicolás Maduro and his inner circle, Vice-President Tareck El Aissami, Minister of Defence Vladimir Padrino Lopez and the High Military Command. I call on the High Representative, Madame Mogherini, to take the necessary measures in this regard. The elections in Venezuela must be free and fair without any discrimination, qualifications or political prisoners.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, when I was growing up in South America in the 1970s Venezuela was the country that people emigrated to in order to get away from poverty and oppression. How quickly the application of socialism can turn a prosperous, functioning, modern economy into a disaster zone! 800% inflation, running out of food and basic medicines – and, incredibly, documented cases of malnutrition. All the way through the Chavez experiment we had voices on the left in this House and in the national governments cheering it on and saying that it should be a model for our European governments. Now, suddenly, it wasn’t socialism at all – it was sort of an experiment that went wrong, like all of the others, like Yugoslavia, like Romania, like Cuba, China, Russia. It’s always wonderful until it goes wrong, and then it was ‘never proper socialism in the first place’. Invariably the pattern is the same, with the displacement activity we just heard to the effect that, you know, something else bad is happening in Honduras and therefore we shouldn’t care at all. The reality is it was perfect textbook socialism control of an economy that reduced a once—wealthy country to poverty and dirt. When are we going to learn the lesson?  (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, first of all, I express my condolences to the families of the murdered Israeli soldiers, Hadar Goldin and Oron Shaul. Hamas and the Palestinian Authority must return their bodies. In addition, the humanitarian actions in Gaza of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees in the Near East need to be supported, because they are essential, as this agency supports around 5 000 000 Palestinian refugees. We call on the Agency to streamline costs, reduce them, report them to benefits, continue education reforms to bring it into line with UN standards, and condemn Hamas's use of its facilities, which is happening and is not condemned. The Agency remains in need of support. We will ask the Arab states to supplement funding, but the Agency must also be visibly effective.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this resolution, the European Parliament not only reiterates its support for UNRWA's activity, but also reaffirms the principles of international law, first and foremost status of Jerusalem. Rights blatantly violated and trampled by US President Trump with his unilateral decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital in violation of UN resolutions. UNRWA exists not because the Palestinians want it, it exists because Palestinian refugees still exist, driven from their homes and lands, who remain refugees after decades. It exists because Israel continues to occupy territories not its own and Netanyahu's government has in fact boycotted what little remained of the peace process. So it is good for Parliament to reiterate its support for UNRWA, but it is not enough. It's not enough when UNRWA funded schools are boycotted, they get bombed by Israel. As a European Union we have an association agreement with Israel which provides for a suspension clause in case of violation of human rights. It would be time to make her case.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, the reason I became a negotiator for this agreement was to remove what mine said before the speaker. To get this whole thing politicized. This is not a match between UNRWA, this organisation, this is not a match between Israel and Palestine, this is not a match between the European Union and the United States, this is about us having to help people who need it. But we must also have claims to this organization at the same time. We must make it clear that we are not going to suffer the need for textbooks on how to attack Israel, and we must also say that we will not support any schools that are named after terrorists. This thing is not political. This is humanitarian and I hope that even after this resolution the European Parliament will see it this way.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I supported the procedure of the part of the European Parliament, which thinks it is good for us to introduce only one time so as not to alternate summer and winter time. I believe that nowadays, when even experts clearly say that alternation of time does not bring any economic benefits, so maintain the rotation of time at the moment when it causes problems for certain groups of the European population, the elderly, sick people, young children, I think they lose their sense. That is why I think it is a good thing that we have adopted a resolution today, albeit in the softer form, and it would be a good thing for the European Commission to deal with this and that, over time, we really keep in Europe only one time that will not cause problems for any group of our people and will not even cause problems for certain types of livestock.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, as the only Irish member on the ad hoc committee which has been looking at clock change for a couple of years now, I want, on behalf of my country, to thank Parliament firstly for putting this into the debate today, which unfortunately I couldn’t attend, because it clashed with shadows’ meetings that I had to engage in, but also for the vote that we have had here today. The vote is very conclusive. 384 voted in favour of the resolution, 153 against and 12 abstained. So now there’s a clear imperative for the European Commission to take this seriously, do a thorough assessment and then, hopefully, as a result of that assessment, come forward with a legislative proposal that will – hopefully – end this biannual change, which our evidence suggests is good neither for man or beast nor for energy.

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: — Mr President, I usually tend to be very critical of the European Union, but on this matter I must say that today the European Parliament has adopted a resolution, which actually opens the way for deregulation in the case alternation of winter and summer time. For interest, in Russia they canceled the alternation of winter and summer time already seven years ago. If we hurry up, and I understand that everything takes us longer in the European Union, our delay against Russia will not be so great. If we agree that the alternation of winter and daylight saving time should be abolished, then I am very subscribing to the abolition of winter time. To keep the time of summer for the European Union permanently.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, colleagues, in dealing with the issues that closely touch the everyday lives of European citizens, we have to stick to the evidence-based approach. The research that has so far been produced by the European Commission has shown that the summer-time change has very little impact on a person’s well-being. In addition to energy savings, it provides major opportunities for evening activities. Certainly we should encourage further research into this topic to find new evidence. If the need to stop changing the clocks is underpinned by the national governments, there will be a reason for us to consider adopting a relevant regulation. Otherwise, if this issue is not a priority for citizens or for the governments and would not bring meaningful benefits to the internal market, what is the reason for adopting new measures here in the European Parliament? Personally, colleagues, I’m not convinced so far about the need to change the current arrangements and I therefore voted against the resolution calling for the summer-time clock change to be stopped.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, I would like to remind myself that I first met this initiative at an ordinary baker in a small village near Chrudimi. His name was Peck's baker. And that's when Peter Pithart promised him in the election fight that if he supported him in the second round, he would push for that change in the alternation of summer and winter time. Unfortunately, that didn't happen. Then Petr Šilar began to promote it, and subsequently it also got into our programme. I, for one, don't think today's vote would be crucial in any way. But I think that feels good for us to just change that run-down routine of alternating daylight and winter time that has no economic and other meaning. And I don't think it does matter if it's summer or winter time. I think that we who voted in favour of this resolution are most bothered by that time being rotated. And hopefully we'll live to see that cancellation someday.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, 384 votes for and 183 against are a clear sign to the European Commission that it needs to address the analysis of the calculation of summer and winter weather and need evidence. In any case, I personally advocate for daylight saving time and I hope that most of our citizens of the European Union, and Croatia, support it. In any case, it's about saving energy, it's about health. However, without thorough research we would not be able to talk about this and that is why we voted today for a Resolution that sends the Commission to further research. Hopefully it will come to this result that most of us want, which is daylight saving time.
